oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cameron, James, 1817-1882
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Colonel and Mrs. James A Whiteside, Son Charles and Servants
Cameron, Whiteside Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The scene depicts the James A. Whiteside family, including Mr. Whiteside (1803-1861), his wife Harriet (1824-1903), a son and two family slaves sitting on the veranda of their home overlooking the Moccasin Bend of the Tennessee River as it runs through Chattanooga.

The setting for this painting is atop Lookout Mountain, where Colonel Whiteside, seated at center right, built the Lookout Mountain Hotel. James A. Whiteside brought James Cameron, who painted this scene, to Chattanooga in the early 1850s. Cameron made the painting as a gift to his patron.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fisher, Flavius J. (1832-1905)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The View of Knoxville
Knoxville, panoramic view
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic, sparsely-settled landscape showing river bend at left, bridge across the river in the center of the composition, and low hills across the river.

This landscape view of the Tennessee River at Knoxville is seen from a height in the vicinity of Fort Sanders or the University of Tennessee. The completed railroad bridge confirms its post-Civil War date. Artist Flavius Fisher, who was born in Virginia and had grown up in East Tennessee, is known to have studied in Philadelphia until about 1850 and was working in Richmond by 1855. He is known to have painted one or more portraits in Knoxville in the 1850s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Centennial Exposition, Nashville, Tennessee, 1897 / The Henderson Litho. Co., Cincinnati.
Centennial Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bird's-eye view of the Exposition's grounds.

The 1897 Centennial Expositions was designed to honor the 100th anniversary of Tennessee's statehood, however, it was also an opportunity to honor Confederate and Union veterans of the Civil War. Highlights of the Exposition included a cyclorama of the Battle of Gettysburg and the display of memorabilia from the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N. (1819-1902)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville from Mabry's house, looking towards the southwest, March, 1864
View from Mabry-Hazen House, Knoxville, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic view of a river and distant road with a barn and farmhouse in the center of the image and single figure at the far right.

Railroad industrialist Joseph Alexander Mabry's (1826-1882), home, built in 1858 prominently on a hilltop in Knoxville, TN, was an ideal site for photographer George Barnard to record the area's terrain. In 1864, Barnard had been named the official photographer of General William Tecumseh Sherman's Military Command. He photographed this view on March 21, 1864.

Baronne de Charette
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval portrait of Antoinette Polk standing beside a stool and desk

Antoinette Polk, Baronne de Charette, in the days after she was awarded Abel Streight's brigade banner by Nathan Bedford Forrest. Polk earned the recognition for her bravery in alterting the Confederate wounded recovering at Ashwood that a Union unit was approaching the area.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wood, Thomas Waterman (1823-1909)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Rev. Charles Todd Quintard
Quintard, Bishop Charles Todd
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A young male minister in white gown and black stole stands in a church holding a large book. To his right one can see the edge of a pipe organ; behind him is an arched stained glass window.

After the death of Bishop James H. Otey in 1863, Doctor C.T. Quintard became the second Episcopal Bishop of Tennessee. During the Civil War, he served as a chaplain with an elite group of Confederate soldiers, the Rock City Guards, which was organized from Nashville and the surrounding area. After the war, he was appointed Vice-Chancellor of the University of the South, Sewanee, Tennessee where he started a training school for clergy that would become the School of Theology.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McGavock Confederate Cemetery, Franklin, Tennessee
Carnton Cemetery
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scobey family women in the McGavock Confederate Cemetery during the Confederate reunion in Franklin, Tenn.

The McGavock Confederate Cemetery is the nation's largest private Confederate cemetery. Located on 2 acres of the Carnton plantation in Franklin, Tennessee, the cemetery is the burial site for 1481 Confederates killed at the Battle of Franklin. (Carnton served as a field hospital during the 1864 Battle.) Residents John and Carrie McGavock's concern for the remains led to the setting aside of the land and the reinterment of the soldiers in 1866.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wood, Thomas Waterman (1823-1903)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Bit of War History: The Contraband
Wood, The Contraband
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the left hand portion of a triptych showing an African American man in the same location at three stages of his military career. Here, he doffs his hat in greeting as he stands outside of the Provost Marshall's Office. In the background is a U.S. flag, drum, a new rifle with bayonette, and a newspaper lying on a chair. The man carries a knapsack on a stick and has dried tobacco leaves stuffed in his pocket. His clothes are rumpled.

This series of three paintings by Thomas Waterman Wood, created in 1866, depicts the progression of an ex-slave from his enlistment in the Union army to his return as a wounded veteran. Wood, who was living in Nashville in 1862, moved to Louisville in neutral Kentucky for the remainder of the war. His dignified and sympathetic portrayals of African Americans working in the fields or accepting new responsibilities prior to and immediately after the war are so unusual as to become political statements.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Col. Abel D. Streight, 51st Ind. Inf. USA
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bearded figure sits in an upholstered chair

Abel D. Streight (1828-1892) was a Union Army general in the Civil War. Streight was forced to surrender to Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest on May 3, 1863 in Northern Alabama during a raid authorized by General Rosecrans. The raid originated in Nashville in April 1863 and nearly reached its objective in Georgia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Waud, Alfred R. (Alfred Rudolph), 1828-1891
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Missionary Ridge, Tenn., Nov 25 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two lines of Union troops fire into a wooded area. A cannon is pictured at far left and two bodies are lying on the ground at the picture's center right. Bare trees in the foreground suggest a winter scene.

This illustration by "Special Artist" Alfred R. Waud, depicts events occuring at the Battle above the Clouds. On November 25, 1863 Union forces under Generals Sherman, Thomas and Hooker attacked Confederate General Braxton Bragg's troops at Missionary Ridge along Lookout Mountain near Chattanooga. Sherman was out maneuvered by Confederate General Patrick Cleburne but later support from General Thomas carried the day. Artists like Waud could get closer to the battle than photographers, who were limited by their bulky equipment.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Federal Troops Scaling Roper's Rock Following the Battle of Lookout Mountain
Roper's Rock, Lookout Mountain, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Federal troops employing ladders and scaling cliffs at Roper's Rock following the Battle of Lookout Mountain.

The Battle of Lookout Mountain or the "Battle Above the Clouds," commenced on November 24, 1863, with General Braxton Bragg's Confederate forces in possession of Lookout Mountain. Before daylight the next morning, and in opposition to the wishes of commander General Ulysses S. Grant, Federal volunteers scaled the cliffs of the Palisades, found the Confederates had withdrawn, and claimed Lookout Mountain. The rock was named after U. S. Sergeant Roper, who fell to his death there.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gilbert Gaul, ca. 1900
Artist in his studio
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An artist turns to look at the photographer. He is seated in his studio surrounded by paintings. He holds a brush and palette and appears to be working on a western scene, positioned on the easel in front of him.

Gilbert Gaul, 1855-1919, who received his artistic training at the National Academy of Design, inherited a farm in Van Buren County, Tennessee in 1881. Gaul built a log residence and studio on this land where he lived until 1885. Gaul spent time in Tennessee from 1891 to 1895 and in 1905 began teaching at Watkins Institute in Nashville. In the 1880s, he began to do works commemorating the Civil War, many of which found enthusiastic patrons.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sully, Thomas (1783-1872)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Louisa Pope Miller
Louisa Pope
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frontal bust portrait of a pale young woman. She has brown hair parted down the middle, with ringlets reaching just past her bare shoulders. Plain dark mottled background. The frame encloses the portrait in an oval shape.

Louisa Pope was born and lived in Memphis, the daughter of John Pope, a prominent Memphis cotton merchant. This portrait was painted in New York after Louisa Pope's marriage to Wylie Miller of New York City. The artist, Thomas Sully, studied under Gilbert Stuart and Benjamin West and painted some of the most important figures in the 19th c. world of politics and fashion. His portraits of women are characterized by an soft tones and brushwork; figures frequently have elogated necks and pale skin tones.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Carl Gutherz
Gutherz, Carl
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man is seated in a cushioned, ornate wooden chair. He wears a suit with a watch fob. In his lap, he holds what appears to be a book and a sharpening tool.

Carl Gutherz (1844-1907) arrived in Memphis at the age of 16 with his family in 1860. While Carl never served in the Civil War, he found work as a draftsman for a Memphis arms foundry and is reported to have smuggled contraband for the Confederate troops. In 1870, Gutherz studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. Upon his return to the United States he became an art instructor in St. Louis, helping to establish the St. Louis School and Museum of Fine Arts. During his second tenure in Paris (1884–1896) he attended the Académie Julian.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mathews, Alfred Edward, 1831-1874
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Charge of the first brigade, commanded by Col. M.B. Walker, on the Friday evening of the battle of Stone River …
Stones River, Battle of
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Cin[cinnati], O[hio] : Middleton, Strobridge & Co. Lith.,
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A winter scene with leafless trees and cedars in which two lines of Union soldiers advance toward a line of men positioned on the left at the edge of the forest.

The Battle of Stones River near Murfreesboro, Tennessee, took place around dawn on December 31, 1862 and on and off through January 2, 1863. Much of it centered in the Round Forest area, which would become the site for Hazen’s Monument, one of the earliest Civil War memorials to be built on a battlefield. While considered by many to be a draw, General Bragg’s withdrawal allowed General Rosecrans to claim victory for the North. The timing was critical for the Union victory, as northern morale was low in the days following a disastrous loss at Fredericksburg, Virginia. This important Confederate defeat also reinforced the promise and raised hopes for President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation issued on 1 January 1863.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Linn, Royan
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Grant and Staff on Lookout Mountain, 1863
Grant at scene of the "Battle above the Clouds"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General Ulysses S. Grant on Lookout Mountain near Missionary Ridge in 1863. Four men in uniform pose near the edge of the cliff, while one sits further back on the path. The other four are identified, left to right, as General John A. Rawlins, General J. D. Webster, Colonel Clark B. Lagow, and Colonel Killyer.

In September 1863, the Union brigade holding Chattanooga since that summer was sequestered by Confederate General James Longstreet's troops. General Grant seized Brown’s Ferry as well as Wauhatchie, opening up a supply line to the beleaguered Union troops. General Hooker then attacked Lookout Mountain in what became known as "The Battle above the Clouds” on November 25.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Blue and the Gray
Reunion sheet music
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: St. Joseph, MO: Henry M. Butler
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Gen. Robert E. Lee, in uniform, shaking hands, with the slogan "Let us have peace" printed above them. The remains of the battlefield are shown on the ground around them, including cannon, flags, and a drum.

Union and Confederate veterans of the Civil War began to hold separate reunions as early as the 1870s and by 1890 were organizing joint "Blue and Gray" events. Much of the impetus for these events was the economic recovery of the war torn country. Sheet music like Butler's "The Blue and the Gray" was created to support the country's healing process and appeal to the large numbers of veterans of the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lloyd, J.T.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lloyd's Official Map of the State of Tennessee
Tennessee map
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: J. T. Lloyd and Company, NYC and London
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map depicting major features, especially railroads, present in Tennessee during the Civil War. A large detailed section of Kentucky occupies the top part of the map, and the states surrounding Tennessee receive fringe coverage. Major battle sites in Tennessee are underlined in red.

L. Virginia's diaries report on the toll that McMinnville's occupation by Federal forces--since April 1862--was taking on her health. In an effort to find a safer location, L. Virginia and her children moved from McMinnville, in Warren County, to Beersheba Springs, in Grundy County, to stay with their friends, Colonel and Mrs. John Armfield in the spring of 1863. They were living in Beersheba Springs when it was attacked by Union forces on July 26, 1863.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Walker and Theodore Davis, Civil War artists, full-length portrait, seated on camp stools, facing each other
Special Artists James Walker and Theodore Davis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two men seated on camp stools face each other in a tent-like area, smoking. Both men wear coats, light-colored trousers, and knee-high leather boots. At upper right is a series of holes, possibly bullet holes. Card is signed on reverse: "Very Truly Yours, James Walker."

James Walker (1819-1889) and Theodore R. Davis (1840-1894) were "Special Artists" for news magazines such as Harper's Weekly and Frank Leslie's Illustrated Weekly, illustrating activities at the front. This carte-de-visite is thought to have been made in Chattanooga. While their images were published contemporaneously with the events they depicted, both men are also known to have created later works of art based on their war-time experiences.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1st Regiment Tennessee Infantry, Vounteers of African Descent
Officers of the First Regiment Tennessee Infantry Volunteers of African Descent
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Composite of the officers of the 1st Regiment Tennessee Infantry, Volunteers of African Descent, United States Army.

The United States Colored Troops (U.S.C.T.) in Tennessee experienced every facet of war between 1863 and 1865. In the spring of 1863, General Lorenzo Thomas was appointed Commissioner for the Organization of Colored Troops for the Federal Army in Tennessee. He began actively raising black regiments in Memphis and had 3, 000 troops by June. These first regiments were designated by state and race, such as the 1st Tennessee Volunteers Infantry Regiment, A. D. (African Descent). This unit was organized June 27, 1863, at LaGrange, Fayette County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Slinglandt, Jacob
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Drummer Boy of Shiloh
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Louisville (Ky.): D.P. Faulds & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover depicts fallen drummer boy surrounded by mourning comrades and other casualties as the Battle of Shiloh rages. Cover image has only sepia tint.

The Drummer Boy of Shiloh was a song written for Harpers Weekly magazine by William S. Hays following the Battle of Chickamauga in 1863. The inspiration for drummer boy Johnny Shiloh may have been John Lincoln Clem who served with distinction in the Battle of Chickamauga at the age of 12 and was promoted for his bravery. While it is unlikely that Clem served at Shiloh, many young boys did serve as musicians on the battlefield, leading troops into and out of the fighting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hazen Brigade Monument
Stones River Battlefield, Hazen Brigade Monument
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A rectagular stone monument and tombstones are enclosed by a stone wall. Trees and grass surround the area.

Hazen's Brigade Monument stands in the midst of one of the first official Civil War graveyards, which was built on the battlefield soon after the battle of Stones River. Named after William Babcock Hazen (1830-1887), a West Point graduate who commanded the unit, it is believed to be the oldest intact Civil War monument. Built on the defense line held by the troops on December 31, 1862, the monument's location was selected by Captain A. Johnson of the 9th Indiana Infantry to honor those men of the 9th who held the crest. Hazen's Brigade also figured in the January 2 fighting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Allen and Rowell
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Jubilee Singers, Original Company, 1871-1882
The Jubilee Singers, Original Company from Fisk University, Nashville, Tenn., ; 1871-1882, Eleventh Season.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eleven elegantly dressed students (7 women and 4 men) surround an organ with two of the women seated. Text below notes this is the 11th season of the group's performance. The photograph was taken in the studio of Allen and Rowell, at 25 Winter Street in Boston in 1992. Note the false background pillars to the sides of the photograph.

This photograph shows the original company of the Fisk Jubilee Singers. Excelling in popular sacred music, they toured the United States and Europe raising awareness and money to support Nashville's Fisk University, one of the earliest Historically Black Colleges. Proceeds from a tour of Europe in 1873-74 paid for the university's first permanent building. The handsome building, named Jubilee Hall, is still standing today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John L. Clem, Musician
"Johnny Shiloh" or the "Drummer Boy of Chickamauga"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Uniformed boy standing beside tall musket.

Ten-year-old drummer John Lincoln Clem, of Newark, Ohio, became famous as "Johnny Shiloh" after he was reputed to have survived a shrapnel shell during the Battle of Shiloh. While scholars have been unable to place Clem at Shiloh, he did serve at Chickamauga and was wounded in Atlanta. After the war, President Grant appointed him to the regular army, in which he rose to the rank of Colonel, before retiring in 1903.

Ballads
Making Music

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson, Hugh Cathcart (1829-1919), Architect
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ryman Auditorium
Union Gospel Tabernacle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gabled facade of a 2-story red brick building with rows of lancet window.

In 1888, Thomas Green Ryman commissioned construction of the Union Gospel Tabernacle so that Nashville would have an appropriate venue for the popular evangelical gatherings of the time. A balcony added in 1897, was funded in part by the United Confederate Veterans to accommodate a reunion of their members during the Tennessee Centennial Exposition (Ryman himself never served in the war). The Tabernacle served as their headquarters during the June 1897 three-day reunion and was the starting point for a parade through Nashville. In honor of their support, the Tabernacle's trustees named the addition, "The Confederate Gallery." In 1904, the hall, by then used primarily for concerts and soon to become the first home of the Grand Ole Opry, was re-named the Ryman Auditorium.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.)
Making Music; The Persistence of Memory

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gutherz, Frederick G.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stephens Bluff on the Black Warrior River, taken from the Steamer Lily, May 14, 1864
Gutherz drawing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A grouping of buildings is situated on top of a bluff. Vegetation is sparse with a few trees and shrubs.

Carl Gutherz's older brother Fred joined the 154th Senior Tennessee Volunteer Regiment as an army engineer for the CSA. Fred later served with the Confederate forces fighting Sherman in North Georgia in 1864. The Steamer Lily was a side-wheel steamboat that transported troops through Alabama during the Civil War. Here it transports Fred and other Confederate soldiers down the Black Warrior River, which runs from a forested area of high bluffs at the extreme southern end of the Appalachian Mountains to the suburbs of Birmingham, Alabama.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Walker the Artist and Theodore Davis at work on Lookout Mountain; Civil War; Chattanooga (Tenn)
James Walker and Theodore Davis on Lookout Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two seated artists work outside of a tent on a smoky hillside. A third figure chops wood at lower right.

James Walker (1819-1889) and Theodore Davis (1840-1894) were "Special Artists" for news magazines such as Harper's Weekly and Leslie's Illustrated Weekly, illustrating news reports from the front. Here, the artists are working on Lookout Mountain, the scene of "The Battle above the Clouds" in November, 1863.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chattanooga Cordially Invites You to a Barbeque at Crawfish Springs, Walker County, Georgia September 20, 1889
Invitation to Barbeque Dedication of Chickamauga National Battlefield Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Several vignettes showing a uniformed Union and Confederate veteran preparing for a barbeque by selecting a pig and building a fire. Crossed pipes with the letters "CV" and "A of C" frame a scene with a train crossing an elevated track over a river with a waterwheel. The stars and stripes appears at left. Two crawfish appear above text at bottom.

This barbeque, held at Crawfish Springs, Georgia, near Chattanooga, Tennessee, was the first joint Blue-Gray reunion organized in Tennessee. Veterans of the Army of the Cumberland, led during the war by Confederate General Rosecrans, reunited with Union soldiers near the site of the Battle of Chickamauga in September 1889. In 1890, Chickamauga was appropriated $325,000 as the first American battlefield to be preserved by Congress. The development of the area, including rail infrastructure, made the location, then called Crawfish Springs, an accessible and pleasant vacation spot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Reunions; Railroads
The Persistence of Memory

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Major W. D. Reynolds
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miss Martha Brownlow, Or the Heroine of Tennessee

The Heroine of Tennessee : a truthful and graphic account of the many perils and privations endured by Miss Martha Brownlow, the lovely and accomplished daughter of the celebrated Parson Brownlow, during her residence with her father in Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Philadelphia: Barclay & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Booklet; the cover image is an illustration of Susan Browlow, daughter of William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow.

This novel, written by Major W.D. Reynolds, tells the story of Susan's reputed saving of the U.S. flag which was flying over the home of her father, William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow while Knoxville was controlled by the Confederates. Reynolds uses a pseudonym for Susan--Martha--possibly to protect her identity. Susan and her father travelled during the war selling their novels (he had his own) and making speeches about the defiant Unionists living in East Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Fiction

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stone's River National Cemetery
Reburials at Stone's River National Cemetery
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: J. A. Stoddard & Co. Chicago, Illinois
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published and sold in behalf of a fund for ornamenting cemeteries in the states of Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia, under the sanction of Maj. Gen. G. H. Thomas, commanding the department. WM. Earnshaw, U.S.A., Superintendent

Reinterrment of Union dead at Stones River National Cemetery was under the charge of Chaplain William Earnshaw. Private William Holland, a Tennessean in 111th United States Colored Troops, served under Earnshaw. He later owned a small farm near the cemetery, where he is buried.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jug, detail
Two handled, glazed pottery jug
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ceramic jug with two handles, impressions, and decorative red and green glazes.

Christopher A. Haun, 1821-1861, was one of five men from Greene County who were a part of a plot to burn river and railroad bridges to impede the Confederate advance in November 1861. They were captured and hanged. Haun and several of the others worked in the aptly-named Pottertown.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Unknown photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Speakers Stand at the Blue and Gray Barbeque, Crawfish Springs, GA, September 20, 1889
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Crowd shot taken from above the water wheel.

This joint reunion of Union and Confederate veterans of the Battle of Chickamauga, at Crawfish Springs, Georgia, on September 20, 1889, set a precedent that ultimately resulted in the formation of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park. Led by a committee of experts from both North and South, the Chickamauga project became a model for battlefield reconstruction. Over 50,000 visitors attended the dedication of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park in 1895.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Morse Gallery of the Cumberland
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Belmont Mansion and Formal Garden
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mansion facing on gardens landscaped in three circular sections with pathways and plantings. One circle surrounds a fountain, one a gazebo, and the other a flower garden. Four additional gazebos flank the house and grounds.

Architect and engineer Adolphus Heiman oversaw the remodeling and additions to this Italinate house just prior to the Civil War. The formal geometric gardens of Belmont are designed to complement the lines of the home. Typically, the decorative gardens of a large home were used as an approach in the front of the house, encouraging visitors to admire the building, and functional vegetable, herb and cutting gardens were placed in the rear of the building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ladies of Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: U.S. Flag given to Susan Brownlow by the Ladies of Philadelphia, June 13, 1862 for her courageous defense of the flag flown over the Brownlow home in Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Flag with thirteen red and white alternating bars, blue union with eagle and stars, and a gold fringe border. Inscription reads "Liberty & Union. Now & Forever, One and Inseperable [sic]."

Susan Brownlow Sawyers Boynton (1837-1913), the daughter of pro-Union Knoxville Whig newspaper publisher William Gannaway “Parson” Brownlow (1805-1877), whose brothers John and James were serving in the Union army, was reputed to have barred Confederate troops from removing the Union flag flying over her home at great personal risk. The Ladies of Philadelphia gave Susan Brownlow this flag in honor of her heroism.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Palmer, Samuel Bell
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gay Street, Knoxville, Tenn. 1861
Simultaneous Recruiting for Confederate and Union Armies on Gay Street, 1861
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This drawing depicts a crowd gathered on Gay Street in Knoxville, Tennessee for the purposes of recruiting Union and Confederate soldiers.

The personal art of soldiers reveals not only their skills at carving or drawing but also what they felt most important to communicate. This drawing, which Palmer completed in 1863 while imprisoned at Camp Douglas, near Chicago, gives a vivid sense of how evenly split loyalties were in the city of Knoxville right after the secession vote, June 8, 1861, when a majority of Tennesseans voted to join the Confederacy. A Confederate training camp was set up across from Old Gray cemetery and 400 soldiers were housed in Knoxville. Although young men in rural sections of East Tennessee were more likely to be Union loyalists, Palmer and others like him in the cities joined many sons of wealthy and prominent families, such as the McClung and Ramsey families in Knoxville, in signing up for the Confederacy. Many Confederate soldiers set down images of their war experiences, sent home illustrated letters, and kept journals. So also did Union troops, many of whom had never before ventured south.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Newman, Robert Loftin (1827-1912)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stonewall Jackson
Portrait of General Stonewall Jackson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of a pair of portraits (with Robert E. Lee) that may have been created in Clarksville, Tennessee after the Civil War. The other pair is in a private collection that originated in Clarksville, Tennessee.

This portrait of Confederate General Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson (1824-1863) has been attributed to artist Robert Loftin Newman, a Virginian who had a studio in Clarksville, Tennessee in 1858. Newman served in the Confederate Army, returning to Tennessee after the war before moving to New York City for the remainder of his life. These are among his only known Civil War themed works. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Clarksville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Sanders, Knoxville, Tennessee showing bastion which was assaulted on the morning of Nov. 29, 1863
Babcock, Orville and Orlando Poe at Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Poe and Babcock are shown in the foreground against a landscape decimated by the battle of Fort Sanders.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. Orlando Poe and Orville Babcock were West Point graduates and engineers. Poe worked under Gen. Ambrose Burnside in Knoxville, Tennessee, to fortify the city after it was occupied by Federal troops in September 1863. Babcock served as an aide to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Weeden, Maria Howard
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Uncle Man, side view
Wessyngton Plantation, former slave, Emmanuel Washington
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Depicts an elderly African American man with short white beard and wearing a cloth cap and plain buttoned shirt with pointed collar. This accomplished portrait was done in soft tones of gray and brown with dark shading of facial features. This drawing gives an alternate view: a right side profile.

Maria Howard Weeden, 1846-1905, was born in Huntsville, Alabama. She developed her natural artistic abilities while attending Tuskegee Female Methodist College just after the Civil War. Weeden, best known for her sympathetic images of former slaves, also spent time in Tennessee. This portrait is of Emmanuel Washington, who remained at Wessyngton in Cedar Hill, Tennessee after the Civil War where he was employed as a cook for the Washington family.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unidentified soldier at Point Lookout
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified soldier in Union officer's uniform at Point Lookout, Tennessee, sitting with cavalry saber in hand and slouch hat resting beside him on a rock.

In late 1863, after the battles of Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge, the pair set up a studio near Point Lookout. Here they photographed the western Union armies as they concentrated for an advance on Atlanta. (Source: Matthew R. Gross and Elizabeth T. Lewin, 2010)

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tenn. Railroad Yard and Depot with Locomotives; the Capitol in Distance
Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad Depot with Tennessee State Capitol on Hill at Right
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scene of rail yard and Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad Depot designed by architect and engineer Adolphus Heiman. Tennessee State Capitol visible in the background. Four locomotives stand next to the depot. Tents behind building to the right of the depot.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army with offices based at 89 Church Street in Nashville beginning in December 1863. Nashville had been captured by Federal troops in February of 1862 and Chattanooga had fallen in November 1863. Barnard traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. His focus in his work was the locations of strategic interest to the military: railroads, bridges and battlefields. Between January and September of 1864 Nashville was the scene of great activity as approximately 140,000 troops and immense amounts of supplies passed through the city as the Federal campaign moved south.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lotz, Johann Albert
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lotz House Façade
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Greek revival style, two story wood frame house in Franklin, Tennessee. Decorative carved scroll and floral ornament in pediment and on front support columns.

Lotz designed and built this house, which is located across the street from the brick home of Fountain Branch Carter. Lotz, a skilled carpenter and German immigrant, created furniture for the home interior and for many patrons in the area prior to the Civil War. During the Battle of Franklin, 30 November 1864, Lotz and his family took shelter at the Carter house. His house survived with surprisingly little damage.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Abel Streight Brigade Banner
United States Brigade Flag
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The flag appears to have been trimmed, particularly in the blue field and the border areas, with possible portions taken as souvenirs. The fabric is faded, particularly the red and white stripes. It has a blue field with gold stars and a fringe border.

Antoinette Polk, daughter of Andrew Jackson Polk of Ashwood Hall, was sixteen years old and visiting her cousins in Columbia when she heard that Union Gen. John T. Wilder’s “Lightning Brigade” was approaching. Knowing that there were Confederate soldiers recuperating at her home, she jumped on her horse and raced home in time to warn the soldiers. When Colonel Nathan Bedford Forrest heard of Antoinette’s bravery, he gave her this banner captured from Union Gen. Abel Streight’s Brigade in May 1864.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Shaver, Samuel M. (1816-1878)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Susan Penniman Dickinson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The portrait shows a seated woman with a red drape at left and a house at right. She appears to be in young middle age and wears a cameo and lace collar and cuffs.

This painting portrays Susan Penniman Dickinson, a native of Massachusetts, was married Perez Dickinson in Suffolk County, Massachusetts in 1845. The house in downtown Knoxville where they most likely lived with Dickinson's brother-in-law James Estabrook and his family appears to be shown in the background. This may be a posthumous portrait. Susan Penniman Dickinson died in 1846. Dickinson purchased the house from Estabrook in 1851. The portraitist, Flavius Fisher, who had grown up in East Tennessee, is known to have studied in Philadelphia until about 1850 and was working in Richmond by 1855. His crayon drawing of Annie White, Dickinson's niece, is thought to have been made about 1857.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wood, Thomas Waterman (1823-1903)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Southern Cornfield, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This painting depicts eight African Americans of varying ages working in a field of corn, probably under a hot June sun. The moment shown appears to be a break for water.

Thomas Waterman Wood, a native of Vermont, trained as an artist in Boston and New York and traveled in Europe before settling in Nashville in 1859. He was drawn to the cosmopolitan southern city by the promise of portrait commissions, but he undertook this genre painting, for which he hired models, on his own. He left Nashville in 1862 for Louisville, Kentucky. What he had seen of African American life must have fascinated him, for he soon undertook a series of paintings that chronicled the transition from slavery to citizenship.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--African Americans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chambers, George W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: In the Tennessee Mountains, 1887
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It depicts a late summer scene in which an elderly woman standing in a garden leaning on a hoe. In the garden are cabbages and tomatoes, a shock of corn stalks is visible at the edge of the garden where there are also flowers blooming. There are two cabins in the background, one of which appears to be in deteriorating condition.

George W. Chambers (b. 1857) taught in Nashville at the Watkins Institute beginning in 1885 and at the Nashville School of Art in the 1890s. A native of St. Louis, Missouri, Chambers had studied under Carl Gutherz (1844-1907) at the St. Louis School of Fine Arts and under Jean Leon Gerome in Paris in 1880. He may have known Gilbert Gaul (1855-1917) who was living in Van Buren County in the 1880s on an inherited farm with outbuildings of a similar design to those in this painting. Cabbages were an important crop for 19th century farmers and were a particular staple of Americans of German descent, who used the vegetable in cooking and pickling. Flowers around the perimeter of the garden were planted to attract useful bees. In the background a pumpkin is visible, set against the fence to support its massive vines. The time of year is probably mid to late fall based on the size of the pumpkin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Gardens; Older people; Women
Holding Fast to Beauty; The Persistence of Memory

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Healy, George P.A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of President James K. Polk
James Knox Polk
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust length portrait of Polk facing to his right wearing a white shirt with black cravat and visible white shirt front.

George Peter Alexander Healy, 1813-1894, painted this pair of portraits while President Polk was in office. The paintings along with furnishings used by the Polks at the White House and later at Polk Place were donated to the ancestral home of James K. Polk by Mrs. Polk's niece.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Island Home, Dickinson Residence
Perez Dickinson Home and Gardens
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-story mansion with well-dressed men, women, and children strolling in gardens and pathways. There are two horse and buggies parked out front.

Island Home was the country residence of prominent Knoxville businessman Perez Dickinson (1813-1901). The Massachusetts-born Dickinson, who remained loyal to the Union, left Knoxville during the early years of the Civil War, returning to resume his partnership in the mercantile establishment of Cowan, McClung & Company after the war. He also purchased Williams Island and 164 acres near the confluence of the Holston and French Broad rivers, constructing the house he called Island Home around 1870.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: RippaVilla Plantation, Spring Hill, TN
McKissack Family Group Including Slaves and Horse and Mule in Front of House
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph taken in a grove of trees left of the front entrance to the brick mansion. Group includes older man in bowler hat, several African American women, one holding a small child, several women and children, and a middle aged man, possibly an overseer, standing next to a mule and a horse.

The William McKissack family, originally from North Carolina, moved to Spring Hill in 1834. They brought with them slaves who learned to make bricks. McKissack's brick yard supplied materials for this and other substantial houses in the area. Descendants of Moses McKissack formed one of Tennessee's first architectural and engineering firms. McKissack and McKissack, still in operation today, is one of the nation's oldest and largest African American owned architecture firms.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Books, miniature
Marble books
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two small carved marble volumes standing on end.

These two small books, carved from fragments of the cornerstone of the University of the South, which was destroyed by Union soldiers on July 13, 1863, were later returned to the University. The marble for the cornerstone was ordered from James Sloan of Nashville, who also supplied the East Tennessee marble for the interior of the Tennessee State Capitol.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ashwood Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph with several people on porch and a man on a horse. The image was published in the History of Homes and Gardens of Tennessee in 1936. It was captioned "from an old photograph: Anderson's, Columbia."

This house was built in 1837 for Leonidas Polk, later known as the "Fighting Bishop" of the Confederacy. Trained at West Point, he entered the ministry and moved with his family to Louisiana in 1841 after his appointment as the Bishop of the Southwest Territory. He sold the house to his younger brother Andrew Jackson Polk whose daughter Antoinette performed a heroic deed during the Civil War by warning Confederate soldiers of an impeding Union troop advance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dury, George
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of W.G. Brownlow
Governor William Gannaway Brownlow
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Full length portrait of William G. Brownlow standing in front of a red chair while gesturing toward the United States flag.

Professional artists dependent upon wealthy patrons risked losing business as a result of partisan attitudes. Some left Tennessee, moving either north or further south to avoid having to take sides publicly.Those who stayed carefully toed the line of neutrality, like painter-photographer George Dury, who painted figures from both sides of the war. The Reconstruction Legislature also funded the bust-length portrait of President Abraham Lincoln. Dury was paid $1,000 for the portrait of Brownlow and $225 for the portrait of Lincoln. Both portraits hung in the Tennessee State Capitol. During the Civil War period, Dury also painted Jefferson Davis, Gen. P. G. T. Beauregard [CSA], Gen. William Rosecrans [USA], Gen. George Thomas [USA], and Andrew Johnson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dury, George
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Self Portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Self-portrait of George Dury as a young man.

George Dury, 1817-1894, migrated to America from Bavaria and had established an art studio in Nashville by the early 1850s. This portrait was painted prior to his arrival possibly while a student in Munich.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville, Tenn., March 1864 From Fort Negley Looking North East
Fort Negley
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This panoramic photograph taken from an upper level of the fort shows log construction, earth walls reinforced with stone, and bunker-like structures, as well as uniformed Union soldiers, tents, cannons, and a look out tower. In the distance are low tree-covered hills and a few scattered houses across a relatively flat landscape.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. Fort Negley, a star-shaped fortification, was designed by Army of the Ohio chief engineer James St. Clair Morton and constructed largely by African Americans, both freedmen and conscripted labor. The fort overlooked the junction of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad and the Tennessee and Allatoona Railroad. Barnard later made single views of Fort Negely and the capitol.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville, Tennessee, View from Cupola of East Tennessee University, March 19, 1864
View from Cupola of East Tennessee University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic view from the cupola of East Tennessee University looking East toward the Holston (Tennessee) River with notes on the locations of Forts Stanley, Higley, Dickinson; Battery Noble; and Second Creek.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. This 360 degree photograph was taken on March 19, 1864 by Barnard with the help of Captain Orlando M. Poe. The unusual exposure required the use of seven photographic plates and probably took the two much of the day to complete. Note how few clouds are visible. Because the exposure required to document the landscape usually overexposed the sky, few clouds are visible in most wet plate negatives. In 1866, Barnard would return to Tennessee to document Sherman's earlier campaign for a book. At that time, he took multiple images of the scenes to allow for more detailed views of the sky.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grand Concert by Morgan's Men Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of three performers on stage, one with a violin, one with a banjo, and one dancing, advertising a concert to be performed by Confederate prisoners of war from John Hunt Morgan's cavalry at Camp Douglas. They appear to be performing the minstrel song "Old Robert Ridley." Text underneath describes the program.
Camp Douglas, Chicago, was a prisoner of war camp during the Civil War. Poor conditions in the camp eventually led to the deaths of more than six thousand prisoners.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Simplot, Alexander
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Great Naval Battle Opposite the City of Memphis
Great Naval Battle at Memphis (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The scene depicts Confederate and Union ships in the midst of aa naval battle. In the foreground two ships fire upon each other and groupings of fighting ships are visible at the left, background and right, with one Confederate ship sinking at right. In the far background is a cityscape.

Alexander Simplot, 1837-1914, was a "special artist" who traveled with Union forces from 1861-1863. The painting shows a Union ironclad Monarch, one of five in the battle, in the foreground firing on Confederate Beauregard, which was a remodeled steamboat with cannons on the open-deck. Of the eight Confederate steamboats, all but one was lost. A pencil sketch of this naval battle, also by Simplot, was reproduced as an engraving in Harper's Weekly 28 June 1862.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Presbyterian Church, Interior Looking South
Presbyterian Church, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior shot of church that was used as a hospital during the Civil War.

This Egyptian Revival church was designed by architect William Strickland while he was living in Nashville overseeing the construction of the Tennessee State Capitol. It served as Union Hospital Number 8.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Weeden, Maria Howard
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Uncle Man
Wessyngton Plantation, former slave, Emmanuel Washington
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Depicts an elderly African American man with short white beard and wearing a cloth cap and plain buttoned shirt with pointed collar. This accomplished portrait was done in soft tones of gray and brown with dark shading of facial features.

Maria Howard Weeden, 1846-1905, was born in Huntsville, Alabama. She developed her natural artistic abilities while attending Tuskegee Female Methodist College just after the Civil War. Weeden, best known for her sympathetic images of former slaves, also spent time in Tennessee. This portrait is of Emmanuel Washington, who remained at Wessyngton in Cedar Hill, Tennessee after the Civil War where he was employed as a cook for the Washington family.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Polk Place
Polk Place with Tomb of President James K. Polk
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph was published in History of Homes and Gardens of Tennessee in 1936. It shows the facade of Polk Place with the tomb in the front yard on the right side.

Polk Place, on Capitol Hill, was remodeled by President and Mrs. James K. Polk to serve as a retirement residence after he left Washington when his term concluded in 1848. Polk died 15 June 1849. The state of Tennessee paid for the erection of a tomb on the grounds of Polk Place. Sarah Childress Polk resided at Polk Place during the Civil War and continued to live in the home until her death on 14 August 1891. After which, the home was sold and the tomb was moved to the grounds of the Tennessee State Capitol.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville from Fort Stanley
Knoxville from south side of Tennessee River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic view from south side of the Holston (Tennessee) River showing Union encampment, earthworks, tree stumps, and part of fortification using logs in the foreground. Hand written notes of locations of Fort Sanders, University of East Tennessee, Flint Hill, Temperance Hill, and Mabry's Hill on the opposite side of the river.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. This panoramic view was made with a large 18" x 22" camera. The view from the hilltop looks back toward the city and Temerance Hill from across the river.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N., 1819-1902
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tomb of President James K. Polk
Nashville, Tennessee. Tomb of President James K. Polk
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph shows the tomb of President James Knox Polk during what appears to be winter. There is a tree in the foreground, a brick structure to the left, and other structures behind and below in the distance.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. During the Civil War, the tomb was located on the grounds of Polk Place, the home where Polk and his wife Sarah Childress Polk retired at the end of his term as President. Polk Place, which was on Capitol Hill, is now gone, and the tomb has been relocated to the grounds of the state capitol.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gilbert Gaul's Cabin
Tennessee Cabin, Van Buren County
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph shows a single pen cabin with gable end stone chimney and front porch standing in a cleared field. There is a corner of a log cabin visible at left.

Gilbert Gaul, 1855-1919, who received his artistic training at the National Academy of Design, inherited a farm in Van Buren County, Tennessee in 1881. Gaul built a log residence and studio on this land where he lived until 1885. Gaul spent time in Tennessee from 1891 to 1895 and in 1905 began teaching at Watkins Institute in Nashville. In the 1880s, he began to do works commemorating the Civil War, many of which found enthusiastic patrons.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View from the Top of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., February, 1864
Lookout Mountain, Tennessee, View of Tennessee River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic view from Lookout Mountain of the Tennessee River valley and Moccasin Bend.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. Chattanooga had been captured by Federal troops in November 1863. Captain Orlando M. Poe sent Barnard to Chattanooga in early February 1864 to photograph railroads, battlefields and the area around Lookout Mountain. He was there for about a week, February 5-12, 1864. The images would be used to create maps and plan for William T. Sherman's Georgia campaign. Barnard's photographs are characterized by a spare elegance. Note the seated figure at the far right, a device that Barnard frequently employed to suggest scale.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville, Tenn., vicinity. Military bridge at Strawberry Plains and a fort in the distance, seen from north bank of the Holston
Strawberry Plains Bridge, rebuilt with sentry and ruined chimney
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This shot, from a hilltop overlooking the Holston River, shows a free standing chimney in the left side of the frame, a soldier sitting with gun in hand on a pile of rubble in the right side of the frame, and a bridge spanning the river in the background. On the adjacent hilltop, there is a fortification.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. This bridge across the Holston River was critical to the movement of troops and supplies. It was one of those targeted by the East Tennessee loyalist bridge burners in late 1861.

Lotz House, sofa
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Victorian scroll back sofa with curved arms and exposed wood frame.

Lotz, a skilled carpenter and German immigrant, created furniture for the home of his Franklin, Tennessee house and for many patrons in the area prior to the Civil War. This sofa, which has long been associated with the home, is thought to be the work of Lotz.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Nashville, Tenn. Hospital for Federal officers (Literary Department, University of Nashville; later Lindsley Hall, Peabody Normal College)]
University of Nashville Literary Department
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A massive white crenelated building is guarded by 3 soliders standing at the front door. There are 5 additional soldiers on the rooftop. Two soldiers stand watch at a side entrance at far right, one of whom wears a coat. A face peers out of the open window in the center right of the facade. Two saddled horses and a covered wagon with two horses stand beside what appears to be a blockhouse. No vegetation is visible.

This building, used as a Federal hospital during the Civil War, was designed by architect and engineer Adolphus Heiman. The photograph was taken by George N. Barnard, chief photographer of the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers for the Army of the Cumberland, somtime during 1864. Barnard had moved his office to 89 Church Street in Nashville in December 1863 and was working under the direction of Orlando M. Poe to document the landscape in preparation for mapmaking but he also took the opportunity to photograph strategic buildings like this hospital, Fort Negely, and the capitol.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Washington Family
Wessyngton Plantation, Washington family descendants
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of African Americans sitting and standing against a log fence. The group includes five middle aged men and women, a number of children dressed in light colored clothes and hats, and, second from left, Emmanuel Washington who was called "Uncle Man."
This group of Washington family descendants includes at least one former slave, Emmanuel Washington, also called Uncle Man, who was the paid cook at Wessyngton Plantation after the Civil War.

This red bow was worn by a Polk family cousin during the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McKissack House, Spring Hill, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This house, once owned by relatives of William McKissack, is in private hands today. It was constructed of brick from McKissack's brickyard in Spring Hill, TN.

The William McKissack family, originally from North Carolina, moved to Spring Hill in 1834. They brought with them slaves who learned to make bricks. McKissack's brick yard supplied materials for this and other substantial houses in the area. Descendants of Moses McKissack formed one of Tennessee's first architectural and engineering firms. McKissack and McKissack, still in operation today, is one of the nation's oldest African American owned architecture firms.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thompson Photography Studio
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reunion of the Blue and Gray in Knoxville, Tennessee, October 8-9, 1890
Blue-Gray Reunion, 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph of a barren landscape shows a large tent on the hilltop at left and a two story house on the right. In the middle ground are several figures standing on what may be earthworks remaining from the battle of Fort Sanders.

This was taken from the roof top of the J. D. Cowan house near Cumberland Avenue on the University of Tennessee campus in Knoxville. It shows the "monster tent," with a capacity of 15,000, which was erected for the "Reunion of the Blue and Gray" held on October 8 and 9, 1890.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Walker, James
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Battle Above the Clouds
Battle of Lookout Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This painting shows troops in the foreground massed on a plain below a mountain with some cloud cover. At the base of the mountain, troops can be seen charging forward and clouds of smoke from gun and cannon fire can be seen across the horizon.

Englishman James Walker, 1819-1889, was living in Mexico City during the U.S. - Mexican War and later did a series of panoramic paintings depicting it. He created works during and after the Civil War, including several versions of the Battle of Lookout Mountain. A smaller version, done in 1864, was commissioned by Gen. Joseph Hooker, U.S.A., who is depicted on the white horse at left. Artists like Walker created and often travelled large show piece works like this one to satisfy public audiences in the decades following the war.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Campaigns & battles

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Polk Place Interior
Hallway or Corridor in Polk Place
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph shows what appears to be a hallway or corridor leading into the large room depicted in the other photograph taken at the same time. It appears cluttered and possibly underkept, indicating it may have been taken in the later years of her life.

Polk Place, on Capitol Hill, was remodeled by President and Mrs. James K. Polk to serve as a retirement residence after he left Washington when his term concluded in 1848. Polk died 15 June 1849. His portrait is visible in this photograph at right. Sarah Childress Polk resided at Polk Place during the Civil War and continued to live in the home until her death on 14 August 1891. She remained publicly neutral during the war and was known for her hospitality. The layout of the painting on the left wall suggests that this might be the reception room in Polk Place, as shown in the 1880 Frank Leslie's newspaper image shown in this section.

Marble books
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two small carved marble volumes standing on end.

These two small books, carved from fragments of the cornerstone of the University of the South, which was destroyed by Union soldiers on July 13, 1863, were later returned to the University. The marble for the cornerstone was ordered from James Sloan of Nashville, who also supplied the East Tennessee marble for the interior of the Tennessee State Capitol.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Plan of Fort Henry, Tenn. and Secession Ordnance Stores at Fort Henry, Tenn.
Fort Henry, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This drawing shows an aerial view of Fort Henry, particularly with reference to the Tennessee River. A second drawing on the same sheet is a perspective of log buildings and a wall with a platform stacked with cannonballs in the foreground.

Alexander Simplot, 1837-1914, served as a "special artist" for Harper's Weekly. He arrived with Union Naval commander Andrew Foote's fleet at Fort Henry in 1862. This drawing, which emphasizes the closeness of the fort to the river, may have been created to illustrate the placement of the fort in an area prone to flooding.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Suspension Bridge at Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Painting depicting suspension bridge across the Cumberland River with large three story castellated building (city jail also designed by Adolphus Heiman) near bridge and paddlewheel steamer at landing. Other buildings include the medical college, which was also designed by Heiman.

Architect and engineer Adolphus Heiman designed this suspension bridge spanning the Cumberland River at Nashville. The bridge was completed in 1850 and was used until Confederate forces cut the cables on the night of February 18, 1862 after the fall of Fort Donelson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Healy, George P.A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Mrs. James K. Polk
Sarah Childress Polk
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Polk is facing her left wearing a red off the shoulder gown and a tassel-like hair ornament. She is posed in front of a landscape seated in a red chair with a wood frame. There is what appears to be a brown curtain at left.

Sarah Childress was raised in Rutherford County, near Murfreesboro, the daughter of a successful merchant, tavern keeper, and land speculator. Sarah and her sister were educated at the Daniel Elam School and were tutored by the principal of the Bradley Academy, and so their instruction was on a level with that given to boys. At around age 12 the girls were sent to Nashville's Abercrombie School and then finished their education at the Moravian Female Academy in what is now Winston-Salem. The James K. Polk Ancestral Home has a lovely piece of needlework that Sarah completed while in school. After returning to Murfreesboro, Sarah married James K. Polk on January 1, 1824. Sarah supported her husband by accompanying him to Washington on almost every occasion and by highlighting interesting articles in the newspapers for him to read. During Polk's four years as president, 1844-1848, Sarah opened the White House twice weekly to the public. George Peter Alexander Healy, 1813-1894, painted this image of Mrs. Polk, one of a pair of portraits, while President Polk was in office. The paintings, along with furnishings used by the Polks at the White House and later at Polk Place, were donated to the ancestral home of James K. Polk by Mrs. Polk's niece.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reunion of the Confederate Veterans at the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition, June 22-24, 1897
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Harper's Weekly
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A series of images by artist W.A. Rogers published in Harper's Weekly on July 3, 1897. The largest vignette shows elderly men viewing a display of armaments, ammunition, and military paraphernalia labeled "relics from Missionary Ridge." Other images include a boat on Lake Watauga (1) and grinding wheels from a Confederate powder mill (2).
"United Confederate Veterans Days" at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition drew 74,000 visitors over the course of three days.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Federal Troop Barracks, Gallatin, Tennessee
Gallatin Public Square with Federal Troops
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The image depicts troop formations around a courthouse with cupola. There are five artillery pieces in front of the courthouse, positioned around a large, open square with one pointed down a street. Other vignettes in the scene include a man driving a laden carriage out of the square, a group of soldiers standing around buckets on a fire next to a table, and a couple of soldiers on horseback in the foreground.

E. M. Stark was a photographer in Gallatin, Tennessee. While he may or may not have been involved in the war effort, his drawing provides a detailed, first-hand view of the activity of federal soldiers in this important northern Middle Tennessee city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: French, Lucy Virginia Smith
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Forest Home Quilt
Quilt from Forest Home, McMinnville, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Plum-colored bed quilt with puff filling in medium-sized squares. Embroidered with floral designs, including a central cartouche of several types of flowers and garlands and individual flowers on three sides. The quilt has a darker shade of silk cord fringe on all four edges.

Author Lucy Virginia Smith French (1825-1881) lived in McMinnville and Beersheba Springs during the period of the Civil War. We know from her diaries that Mrs. French grew roses, violets (blue and white yellow), verbenas, fuschias, and geraniums. She embroidered this quilt with images of those flowers. The quilt survived the war and was donated to the Tennessee State Museum by her descendants.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thruston, Gates P.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Antiquities of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Red leather-bound book with gold embossed design of an effigy pot on front cover. Pages are black and white, with engraved images based on drawings of artifacts.

The Antiquities of Tennessee, 1890, was the first published book on Native American excavations in Middle Tennessee. Author Gates P. Thruston, a former general in the Union Army, who had served under General George Thomas during the Civil War, married into a Nashville family after the war. Thruston, who was active in both the Tennessee Historical Society and the Nashville Art Association in the 1880s and 1890s, had been passionate about archaeology since his youth. He donated his extensive collection of artifacts excavated in the Middle Tennessee area to Vanderbilt University.

Defenses of Nashville, Tennessee 1864, 1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Collection of engineering schematics for various fortifications in Nashville: Battery Erwin, Battery Coolidge, Battery for Casino Hill, Fort Morton, Fort Sill, Redoubt for Hill No 210, and the Capitol. Includes plans for Fort Dan McCook and Fort W. D. Whipple in Chattanooga.
Army of the Ohio chief engineer James St. Clair Morton, who designed Fort Negley, is credited with the designs for Fort Morton and the defenses of the Tennessee State Capitol building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Smokestacks and buildings seen against a backdrop of river and mountains, fields, roads, and small gable-roofed buidling in foreground.

The Roane Iron Company, headquartered in Chattanooga, Tennessee, founded prior to the Civil War, expanded and grew in importance in the Tennessee iron industry in the post-war period under the leadership of former Union officer John T. Wilder.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rockwell, Cleveland and R. H. Talcott
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Approaches and Defences of Knoxville Showing the Positions Occupied by the United States and Confederate Forces During the Siege
Knoxville, TN, map showing locations of forces in 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Additional text: "surveyed by direction of Capt. O. M. Poe, Chief Engr Dept of the Ohio, during Dec. Jan. and Feb. 1863-4."

In Tennessee, many sons of prominent Tennessee families had prepared for life as professional soldiers by attending military preparatory academies or obtaining commissions to West Point. When war was declared, they were automatically given rank in whichever army they chose to join. Those who trained at West Point had studied engineering and historical military tactics. The Union army purposely recruited skilled tradesmen into the Corps of Engineers to help build bridges, buildings, boats, and fortifications. Plans from both sides for fortifications and detailed maps and drawings have survived. Much of the military strategy targeted railroads and rivers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sayers, Edward B.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Middle Tennessee
Hand Drawn Map of Middle Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawn in ink on oilcloth, which had been folded into pocket size at one time.

This map was created by Confederate engineer Edward B. Sayers, Captain and Chief Engineer, Polk's Corps, May 6, 1863 in Shelbyville, Tennessee. The key to this map, which appears at left, reads: "pikes, common roads, railroads, bridges in use, bridges destroyed." The map, which also contains signal station locations and notes regarding difficult river crossings, was clearly intended for reconnaisance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Theodore Davis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders photograph of a young man wearing a shirt and tie and a jacket with fur collar and soft beret-type hat with ribbon. He is facing to his right.

Theodore R. Davis (1840-1894) was a special artist who travelled to the battle front to sketch scenes which were sent back to New York for conversion to engravings for Harper's Weekly. Over the course of the war, Davis travelled around the South and is known to have been in Memphis in 1861; he was present with Union forces at Chattanooga and Lookout Mountain in 1863; and then was in Knoxville as he prepared to travel with Sherman on his march to Atlanta. Over 250 of the sketches he created on site were published in Harpers Weekly. After the war, Davis produced more finished paintings of Civil War scenes and consulted on the cyclorama of Atlanta.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Davis, Theodore R., 1840-1894; Artists; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-65

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dury, George
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Abraham Lincoln, 1809-1865, President of the United States
Portrait of Abraham Lincoln funded by the Tennessee Legislature during Reconstruction
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lincoln sitting in red chair facing to his left.

Professional artists dependent upon wealthy patrons risked losing business as a result of partisan attitudes. Some left Tennessee, moving either north or further south to avoid having to take sides publicly.Those who stayed carefully toed the line of neutrality, like painter-photographer George Dury, who painted figures from both sides of the war. The Reconstruction Legislature, also known as the Brownlow Legislature, also commissioned a full-length portrait of Gov. William G. Brownlow from Dury.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barker, Barton L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Barker Walking Cane
Barton Barker Walking Stick, 3rd TN US
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This carved wooden walking stick contains decorations including an eagle, a shield, and a star.

This folk art walking stick was carved by Union veteran Barton L. Barker, possibly from wood procured near the battlefield at Chattanooga. Soldiers often brought home souvenirs from the war such as samples of a captured flag as mementos of their experience. Like the flag, the eagle, shield and star were recognized symbols during the period of the war. The Union shield was symbolic of unity, the desire to preserve the union. Stars often symbolized states (Confederate flags can often be dated by the number of stars in the upper register). The eagle, adopted as the national symbol by Congress in the eighteenth century, was often depicted on Federal drums that led men into battle during the Civil War. Barton Barker served in the 3rd Tennessee Infantry from 1862-1865. He moved to Chattanooga after the war and was active in the Lookout Mountain Post of the Grand Army of the Republic as proud of his membership in the Union Veterans League, since that was reserved for men who had enlisted in the federal army prior to the draft of July 1863.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Staffs (Sticks)
The Persistence of Memory

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Drawings of Confederate Soldiers
Bleak House Tower Drawings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait sketches of two bearded men and one youth.

This drawing, found on the interior plaster wall of the tower of Bleak House--Confederate Memorial Hall on Kingston Pike in Knoxville, Tennessee, is purported to represent three Confederate sharpshooters who killed Union General William P. Sanders on the afternoon of November 17, 1863 as he accompanied soldiers marching up Kingston Pike. The central figure has been identified as Corporal William Raines, 9th Georgia unit. During the siege of Knoxville, Bleak House was being used as Confederate General James Longstreet's headquarters. The home's residents, Louisa Franklin Armstrong and her daughters, remained in second floor quarters, emerging for meals during periods when hostilities allowed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Military personnel--Confederate
Visualizing the War; The Persistence of Memory
Sanders, William P.; Longstreet, James; Armstrong, Louisa Franklin

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bleak House
Confederate Memorial Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Antebellum Italian revival house on landscaped grounds, Kingston Pike, Knoxville, Tennessee.

Bleak House, the home of Robert Houston and Louisa Franklin Armstrong, was one of several fashionable houses of wealthy Knoxvillians built just before the Civil War. Armstrong and other prominent Unionists (such as Perez Dickinson and John J. Craig, who also owned homes of a similar Italianate style), left the city in the early years of the war. Louisa Franklin Armstrong remained in Knoxville and her home was used as the headquarters for Confederate generals James Longstreet and Lafayette McLaws during the 1863 "Siege of Knoxville." On November 18, 1863, Union General William P. Sanders was shot and killed, reputedly by sharpshooters located in the tower. Charcoal drawings of the faces of three men, apparently sketched by federal soldiers, can be found today on the north wall of the tower's interior. Both Confederate and Union veterans visited Bleak House, now a museum called Confederate Memorial Hall, during Civil War reunions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architecture, Domestic
Visualizing the War; The Persistence of Memory

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fiske [sic] University Barracks Early Buildings
Fisk University, showing former Union Army barracks
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image depicts a row of buildings with a continuous long porch that appears to be a destination for people of all ages walking, running, and riding in a carriage. The building appears to be in a fenced complex, behind which can be seen a city view houses, other structures, and a smoke stack.

The Fisk Free Colored School was founded in 1866 on the site of the former Federal Fort Gillem. The barracks were used as university buildings until replaced by more permanent structures. The school was named after General Clinton Bowen Fisk who arrived with Union occupying forces in Nashville in 1862. Enrollment topped 900 students in the first year and, in 1867, the school was incorporated as Fisk University. One of the original barracks buildings remains in use today as the Little Theatre.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N. (1819-1902)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Looking Down the Valley of Running Water Creek Near Whitesides, Tenn -1864- Nashville and Chattanooga R. R. Bridge on the Left
Looking Down Near Whitesides, Nashville & Chattanooga RR Bridge on the Left
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: verso: "Running Water Bridge & Raccoon Valley between Chattanooga, Tenn. & Bridgeport, Ala."
View of wooden railroad bridge and military encampment.

Panoramic view of railroad bridge and encampment outside of Chattanooga. Col. James Whiteside was a Chattanooga industrialist and one of the main supporters of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, which was completed in 1854. Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. Captain Orlando M. Poe had sent Barnard to Chattanooga in early February 1864 to document the landscape, during which time he focused on railroads, battlefields and on the Lookout Mountain area. The bridge near Whitesides was considered a highly strategic location. The bridge had been constructed some months prior to this photograph by Federal army engineers. Note the defensive blockhouse in the foreground.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Boucher, Jack
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wessyngton, Gazebo, Cedar Hill vicinity, Robertson, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS)

Wessyngton, home of the Washington family, was one of the highest producing tobacco plantations in Tennessee at the time of the Civil War. The Washingtons also owned a large number of slaves who built their large brick home of bricks made on the property. Many of the Washington slaves left with Union forces as they occupied Tennessee. Some enlisted when a regiment of United States Colored Troops was organized in Gallatin, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vizetelly, Frank (1830-1883)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Pope's Division at the Levee, Cairo, Junction of the Mississippi & Ohio rivers on its way from New Madrid to Reinforce General Halleck, near Corinth.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published as wood engraving in Illustrated London News, 31 May 1862

Steamer ships at dock at mid-distance, river and other shore in far distance. Soldiers and rail car on dock in foreground. Boats are the new Uncle Sam, Yankee, and Aleck Scott. Verso also includes sketches of: a "Western soldier", "Labourer on levee", and a "loafer", with the note, "These to fill up with."

Frank Vizetelly was a British artist and war reporter for the Illustrated London News. This drawing, which was done on or about April 20, 1862, comes from a collection in Harvard University's Houghton Library (MS Am 1585) that includes 29 Civil War drawings. This image of steamboats at Cairo, Illinois, on the Mississippi River, depicts Kentucky Brigadier General John Pope's Union army troops provisioning before heading south to Mississippi. It was published on May 31, 1862 (p. 554, volume 40, no. 1147) in the Illustrated London News.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Brady, Matthew (ca. 1822-1896)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Susan Brownlow Sawyers Boynton
Brownlow, Susan Photograph by Brady
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of a young woman.

al Note:Susan Brownlow, the daughter of newspaper editor and Unionist William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow, lived in Knoxville during the war. She is reputed to have defied Confederate soldiers by displaying a United States flag. New York-born Matthew Brady, who took this portrait, studied under painter William Page and later under artist and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse at the National Academy of Design. There, Brady was introduced to the daguerreotype and he soon opened his own photography studio. Brady later became famous for his photographs of the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cemetery Railroad Station, Stones River National Battlefield
Stones River National Cemetery Railroad Station
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rural landscape with railroad tracks, telegraph poles, and small depot with "Cemetery" sign. Sign pointing to McFadden's Ford at right.

Soon after the Civil War, the Nashville & Chattanooga Railroad established a station stop at Stones River National Cemetery, begun in 1865 on former battlefield land to hold the remains of over 6000 Union casualties. United States Colored Troops, many from the 111th Regiment, were assigned to collect bodies from the surrounding region, transport them by railroad whenever possible, and reinter them in neat rows under the supervision of Chaplain Earnshaw. By providing direct access to the cemetery at Stones River, the N&C was one of the first railroads to facilitate commemorative pilgrimages to Civil War cemetery and battlefield locations in the ensuing decades.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Cemeteries--Union; Railroads
The Persistence of Memory
