oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cooper, William Browning (1811-1900)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Adelicia Acklen with Horse Bocephalus
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of a dark-haired young woman in elaborate riding dress, standing with a large horse against a treed landscape.

Adelicia Hayes Franklin Acklen was a widow and the mistress of Belmont Mansion at the time of the Battle of Nashville. At the time this portrait was painted, she was married to her first husband, Isaac Franklin. Upon his death, she became one of the wealthiest women in Tennessee and inherited plantation holdings in Louisiana as well as in and around Nashville. She married Joseph Acklen, a lawyer from Huntsville, in 1849, but was again widowed in 1863. During the Civil War, she remained in Nashville but also managed to successfully oversee valuable cotton interests in Louisiana. The night before the Battle of Nashville, as many as 3000 Union troops were encamped upon the grounds of Belmont Mansion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Acklen, Adelicia, -- 1817-1887 -- Portraits; Women
Taking Care of Business
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George (1819-1902)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Sanders
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fortification with two cannon ports and wide trench littered with rocks and debris below. There are tree stumps in right foreground. A uniformed soldier stands on top of fort next to bare flagpole.

According to the fort's designer, Orlando M. Poe, Captain of Engineers, photographer George Barnard took these photographs at Fort Sanders. Barnard, who had worked in the studio of Matthew Brady during the early years of the Civil War, was appointed as official photographer for the United States Army's Military Division of the Mississippi, headquartered in Nashville, in late 1863. Working with the Topographic Branch of the Department of Engineers, he photographed the forts, bridges, and landscapes of East Tennessee during the early months of 1864. Based on drawings of the fort, the solider stands on the western face and the ditch which Orlando Poe had constructed is seen at right. Confederate troops,advancing in the pre-dawn hours, underestimated the depth of the ditch and were not aware that the Union soldiers had poured water over the wall to make it icy. The battle lasted only 20 minutes and resulted in heavy casualties for the Confederacy.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forts & fortifications; Fort Sanders (Knoxville, Tenn.); Poe, Orlando M.; Barnard, George; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Engineering and Construction; United States--Tennessee--Fort Sanders (Knoxville)

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Newman, Robert Loftin (1827-1912)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Wallace Warfield and Son [William Laban]
Warfield, William Wallace, portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This formal portrait is of a well-dressed young gentlemen, posed with a young boy holding his arm and a dog seated below.

William Wallace Warfield was a prominent resident of Clarksville, Tennessee, when artist Robert Loftin Newman opened a studio there in 1858. Newman's large portrait of Warfield and his young son, William Laban, is one of a pair painted for wealthy patrons just prior to the Civil War. Newman was one of the few professional artists in Tennessee to join the Confederate forces. Aside from a post-war pair of portrait drawings of generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson, Newman is not known to have created any war-themed works.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jim Crow Plate
Plate with Jim Crow Image
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This plate was part of a children's ABC or alphabet set of transfer-printed ware created in the early 1880s. The "Jim Crow" rhyme, political satire that depicted African Americans as minstrel-show performers, was widely-known.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mabry, Laura Churchwell (1833-1906)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home after War, Showing Fort and Ditches
Sketch of Earthworks, Mabry's Hill, Knoxville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of a two-story house in a grove of trees, with small hill at right and long cross-hatched double line across the lower portion of image.

This drawing, done by the wife of Joseph A. Mabry during the final months of the Civil War, is inscribed "Home after war, showing fort and ditches" and bears the date 8 Feb 1865. Mabry, a prominent railroad man, paid to outfit a Confederate regiment at the beginning of the war. However, after Knoxville was returned to Union control, he signed an oath of allegiance to the United States and cooperated with Union officials for the duration of the war. This drawing depicts the Mabrys' stately country home on a hill in northeast Knoxville, a location that seems to have served as a vantage point for troops on both sides.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Davis, Theodore (1840-1894)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chattanooga from the Artists Camp
Working at Easel
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white scene of a man standing at an easel on a wooded hillside in the lower right section of image. The landscape he is sketching has a river bend and a low hill.

Theodore Davis and James Walker were two of the most prolific "Special Artists" working in the Chattanooga and Lookout Mountain area for Harpers Weekly and other publications during the Civil War. Here, Davis depicts a fellow artist, possibly Walker, painting a bend in the Tennessee River with the city of Chattanooga featured behind a low hill. After the Confederate defeats of Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge in November 1863, the path to Atlanta was opened for Union forces, who would have been on the move in 1864. Wagons move across a pontoon bridge toward Chattanooga.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chattanooga (Tenn.), Battle of; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Art and the war

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Residence of R. S. Hazen
Mabry-Hazen House
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: W.H. Parish Publishing Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a two-story house in a grove of trees.

This house, which was built by Joseph Mabry circa 1858, was the residence of R.S. Hazen, who was married to Mabry's granddaugher Alice, when the image was taken for inclusion in "The Art Work of Knoxville," a book published in 1895. The Mabry house served as a headquarters for both Confederate and Union troops during the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Topographical Map of the Battle Field of Stone River
Stones River Battlefield Topographical Map
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map showing positions of both armies, as well as geographical features.

This map, created under the auspices of the United States Army Corps, Topographical Engineers, is signed by Radford, Surveyor, National Cemetery. The names of Captain Michler and Major Wei(y)ss, as well as Captains Thruston, and Hinchcomb, and Lieutenant Allen, also appear under the title at lower right. Some months after the December 1863 Battle of Stones River, a monument and a small cemetery were created to honor those men in Colonel William B. Hazen's brigade who had died at Shiloh the previous April as well as those who fell at Stones River. The creation of a national cemetery at Stones River was overseen by Chaplain William Earnshaw and members of the 111th United States Colored Troops who began the work of re-interring Union soldiers in October 1865.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Quintard, Charles Todd (1824-1898)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Balm for the Weary and the Wounded"
Quintard Prayer Book "Balm for the Weary and Wounded"
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Columbia, S.C.: Evans & Cogswell
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior cover bears dedication "with warmest regards" to Mrs. A. O. Harris from C.T. Quintard.

After the death of Bishop James H. Otey in 1863, Doctor C.T. Quintard became the second Episcopal Bishop of Tennessee. During the Civil War, he served as a chaplain with an elite group of Confederate soldiers, the Rock City Guards, which was organized from Nashville and the surrounding area. This book was printed in Columbia, South Carolina, apparently to be issued to Confederate soldiers. According to tradition, a copy was found in the jacket of Leonidas Polk after his death at Pine Mountain, Georgia, on June 4, 1864. After the war, Quintard was appointed Vice-Chancellor of the University of the South, Sewanee, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sloan, James
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sewanee Cornerstone Receipt
Receipt for Tennessee Marble Cornerstone
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This small rectangular receipt, printed in blue ink on white paper bears the trademark logo of Nashville Marble Dealer J. Sloan. It is written to University of the South. Figures for labor and delivery add up to a total of $87.25.

This receipt, made out to the University of the South, reflects the purchase of a hand-wrought marble cornerstone from "J. Sloan Steam Marble Works Market Street Nashville Tennessee" on October 15, 1860. Marble dealer James Sloan of Nashville also supplied the East Tennessee marble for the interior of the Tennessee State Capitol. Two small books carved from the brown variegated marble of the cornerstone, which was destroyed by Union soldiers on July 13, 1863, can also be found in the museum collection of the University of the South.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ladies of Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sewanee Flag
Flag Used during Founding and Dedication of the University of the South
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: United States flag with thirteen red and white alternating bars, blue field with 13 stars surrounded by a circle of 18, and a gold fringe border. The flag is faded and several sections of fringe are missing.

This presentation flag, which bears the 31 stars of the United States after admission of California in 1851, was carried in the University of the South's initial founding ceremony, which included a patriotic procession on Lookout Mountain on July 4, 1857. It was also used at the dedication marking the University's permanent location on October 10, 1860. Although founded three years earlier by Bishops Leonidas Polk and James Hervey Otey, a permanent location was not obtained until just before the Civil War. The war and its aftermath delayed the start of classes at the University until 1867.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Newman, Robert Loftin (1827-1912)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Adelia B. Warfield and Daughter [Huldah Belle]
Warfield, Adelia Boisseau, portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A young woman dressed in an off the shoulder gown of shiny fabric, with a light shawl around her upper arms, rests her right hand on the shoulder of a young girl in a fancy dress with white bloomers. The two are standing on a balcony-like terrace overlooking a landscape with river below.

Adelia Boisseau Warfield and her husband William Wallace Warfield were prominent residents of Clarksville, Tennessee, when artist Robert Loftin Newman opened a studio there in 1858. Newman's large portrait of Adelia and her young daughter, Huldah Belle, is one of a pair painted for these wealthy patrons just prior to the Civil War. Newman was one of the few professional artists in Tennessee to join the Confederate forces. Aside from a post-war pair of portrait drawings of generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson and a flag design for the Confederacy, Newman is not known to have created any war-themed works.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hunt Phelan Used as Western Sanitary Hospital, 1863
Soldiers Home, Memphis Tennessee, Established by the Western Sanitary Commission, February 8, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval photograph of white-columned house with substantial outbuildings and grounds, with a number of men and a horse and carriage in foreground. Two small round photographic portraits of a woman and a man below the larger image and an inscription give their names with the titles matron and superintendent.

The home of William Hunt, just outside of downtown Memphis, was occupied by both Confederate and Federal officers during the war. The inscription on this photograph indicates that it was taken over by the Western Sanitary Commission on 8 February 1863 for use as a "soldier's home," under the jurisdiction of the matron and superintendent pictured here. The imposing brick mansion is also thought to have been a Freedmen's School for several years before it was returned to the Hunt family.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cooper, W.B.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of John McGavock
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of a young, dark-haired man facing forward with his right hand holding the fold of his jacket at chest height. He is wearing a formal white shirt and vest, with dark tie and coat. The canvas appears to have been cut down at the sides, perhaps to fit a frame other than the original.

John McGavock (1815-1893) was the owner of Carnton Plantation, just outside of Franklin, Tennessee, during the Civil War. His wife, Carrie Winder McGavock (1829-1905), who was present when the house and yard were used as a makeshift hospital after the Battle of Franklin on 30 November 1864, oversaw the burial of as many as 1500 Confederate soldiers in a cemetery on the grounds.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 79th Scottish Highlander Reunion at Bleak House
Reunion of Veterans of the 79th New York Highlanders, Knoxville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph in round format mounted to card showing a group of elderly gentlemen wearing dark suits, many with pointed caps and two leaning on canes, standing on a roof top next to a brick tower.

The 79th New York Highlanders was originally formed as part of the New York State militia. A wood engraving showing the group marching in Scottish parade dress, created by artist Winslow Homer, was published in Harper's Weekly 329 (25 May 1861). They fought in the defense of Knoxville at Campbell's Station and Fort Sanders in November 1863. This image captures a group of veterans in Knoxville for a Civil War reunion. They are apparently standing on the roof of Bleak House. A monument erected in honor of the 79th NY Highlanders, still stands at 16th and Clinch in the Fort Sanders neighborhood of Knoxville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cooper, W(ashington) B(ogart), 1802-1888
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Carrie McGavock
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of a young dark-haired woman in an off the shoulder dress with lace sleeves seated in front of a red curtain and next to a round marble-topped table.

It is possible that this portrait was done to commemorate the marriage of Carrie Elizabeth Winder (1829-1905) to John McGavock in 1848. Their plantation home, Carnton, on the outskirts of Franklin, Tennessee, was used as a hospital after the Battle of Franklin on 30 November 1864. Carrie McGavock not only oversaw the care of the wounded in and around her house, she was responsible for making sure that nearly 1500 Confederates were reinterred in a cemetery on the McGavock property. She has been immortalized in a fictional portrayal, The Widow of the South, by author Robert Hicks.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bills Cottage
Cottage at The Pillars
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small white wooden building with side gable roof, off-center front door topped by a rectangular paneled glass window and shuttered front window.

This white wooden cottage, with carved scrollwork detail below gabled eaves and and gothic arches adorning the square hoods over its single front window and door, was built during the Civil War by John Houston Bills. Bills, a prominent cotton factor, had been a close associate of President James K. Polk. An anti-war Unionist, he built this cottage in the yard adjoining his home, The Pillars, so that his daughter, who was married to Confederate officer Marshall Polk, a relative of James and Sarah Polk's, could move back into town while her husband was away. Sarah Polk's influence assured that Marshall Polk would receive special care and attention after he was wounded during the war. Emmaline and Marshall presented a gold-tipped cane to Sarah Polk in appreciation.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architecture, Domestic; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Bills, John Houston
Holding Fast to Beauty
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dury, George (1817-1894)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Sarah Polk in Mourning Attire
Polk, Sarah Childress, Portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval portrait of an elderly woman wearing a stiff white collar, a dark dress with buckle pin and a dark veil of mourning.

This portrait of Sarah Childress Polk (1803-1891) shows her in mourning clothing, which she wore from the time of former President James K. Polk's death in 1848 until the end of her life. The white collar and band on her veil and the brown leather of the distinctive buckle brooch she wears at her neck are the only touches of color in her attire. Sarah Polk remained at Polk Place in Nashville after her husband's death. She was in residence during the Civil War and at the time this portrait was painted by artist George Dury.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portraits; Women; Polk, Sarah Childress (1803-1891); Artists

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dury, George (1817-1894)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Little Louise Thruston
Thruston, Louise, portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval portrait of a young blonde girl holding a bunch of roses to her chest.

This is apparently a mourning portrait of Louise Thruston, the daughter of Gates P. Thruston and Ida Hamilton, who died in 1874 at the age of four. She wears an off shoulder white garment and appears as if she is standing inside a cloud. Thruston, a former Union officer, married the daughter of a prominent Nashville family soon after the Civil War. He was a founding member of the Nashville Art Association, predecessor of the Nashville Museum of Art, whose collection now belongs to Cheekwood Museum of Art.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gaul, Gilbert (1855-1919)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Last Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fallen soldier clutching a letter to his chest in a setting of forest and rocks.

This black, white, and gray painting was published in The Century Illustrated Magazine in December 1890 to accompany the sentimental poem "Marthy Virginia's Hand" by George Parsons Lathrop. Gaul, born too late to witness the war first hand, began during the 1880s to create works that reflected the public's interest in remembering the Civil War. He inherited a farm in Van Buren County Tennessee in 1881 and lived there until 1885, visiting and teaching in Tennessee from time to time during the decades that followed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Columbia Female Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This black and white image of the corner of a large building shows a castellated tower covered with vines. A classical statue of a woman with bowed head wearing a long dress with draped folds stands in the yard in front of the building.

The Columbia Female Institute was one of Tennessee's most important schools for young women in the antebellum period. It was founded in 1835 by prominent citizens of Columbia, including Episcopal Bishop of Tennessee James Hervey Otey and Reverend Leonidas Polk. One of its early headmasters, Reverend Franklin Gilette Smith, left the school in 1852 to found the rival Columbia Athenaeum. The Columbia Female Institute closed in 1862 due to the onset of the Civil War and is thought to have served for a time as a federal hospital during the war. It continued in operation until 1932.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Columbia Athenaeum; Columbia Female Institute; Women; Hospitals; Girls' schools; Otey, James Hervey, 1800-1863; Smith, Franklin Gillette, 1797-1866; Polk, Leonidas, 1806-1864

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Cameron (1817-1882)
Cameron, James, portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio photograph of a dark haired man with receding hairline standing next to a curtain with his right hand on the curved back of a chair.

This portrait by an unknown photographer shows Scottish-born artist James Cameron at the approximate age of forty, about the time he would have been working in Tennessee. Cameron's portraits and landscapes dating from the 1850s record settings in and around Chattanooga, Knoxville, and Nashville. One of his most important patrons was James A. Whiteside, a wealthy Chattanooga industrialist and railroad investor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Columbia Athenaeum
Athenaeum, Columbia, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A young woman leans against one of the front portico columns of a whitewashed Greek Revival building bearing the letters Columbia Athenaeum in the pediment.

The Columbia Athenaeum, a school for young women in Columbia, Tennessee, was founded in 1852 by Reverend Franklin Gillette Smith (1797-1866) after he left the Columbia Female Institute, where he had been headmaster since 1837. During the Civil War, Smith and his wife worked tirelessly to keep the Athenaeum boarding school open for any young ladies who cared to stay, fearful that the buildings might be destroyed in their absence.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wood, Thomas Waterman (1823-1903)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Jane Erwin (Yeatman) Bell
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of a dark-haired, middle aged woman wearing black clothing and standing in front of a drapery, with a distant landscape view of a river bend visible to her right.

At the time this portrait was painted, Jane Erwin Yeatman Bell was married to Tennessee Senator John Bell, who had been the Constitutional Union Party candidate for President of the United States in 1860. Very popular in Tennessee, his party had hoped to maintain the Union without challenging the institution of slavery. Her first husband, ironmaster Thomas Yeatman, had left her a wealthy widow upon his death in 1833. When war came to Tennessee, two of the Yeatman sons remained loyal Unionists, one served as an officer, the other appointed to head the Western Sanitary Commission. The younger son, Henry Clay Yeatman, who had married into the Polk family in Maury County, served as an aide to Confederate General Leonidas Polk. Artist Thomas Waterman Wood (1823-1903), a native of Vermont, trained as an artist in Boston and New York. He came to Nashville in 1859 and created portraits for wealthy and prominent patrons for several years before moving north to Louisville at the onset of the Civil War.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portraits; Women; Bell, John, 1796-1869

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gaul, Gilbert (1855-1919)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leaving Home
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This living room scene, which takes place in a house with fireplace located in a wooded setting, shows a young man in gray Confederate uniform clasping the hands of a gray-haired man, while two young women stand behind a seated weeping woman. An African American man and woman stand witnessing the scene, as do two dogs and a cat, while a young African American man stands in the doorway holding a horse by the reins.

Artist Gilbert Gaul, who is known to have been teaching in Nashville about the time this was painted, may have based in people and places that he knew from near his inherited farm in Van Buren County, Tennessee. Gaul, too young to have served in the Civil War, created popular genre scenes and battle images, many of which were published as color lithographs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George (1819-1902)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville, Tenn., vicinity. Bridge at Strawberry Plains, 20 miles northeast of Knoxville; camera on tripod at right
Bridge at Strawberry Plains
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of a standing soldier resting his gun on end next to the near side of a railroad bridge whose wooden rail bed is supported by stone pillars.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army. He traveled to Nashville, Knoxville, and Chattanooga in 1864. This bridge across the Holston River was critical to the movement of troops and supplies. It was one of those targeted by the East Tennessee loyalist bridge burners in late 1861.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Its Memory Alone Remains medal
Fort Sanders, reunion medal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cast and stamped round metal disk with the words "Fort Sanders. Its Memory Alone Remains" around the edge and the image of a large bunker with the Stars and Stripes flying above. The disk is attached to a red, white, and blue silk ribbon hanging from a stamped metal bar pin.

This medal, designed to be pinned to the chest, may have been created for the first 1890 Blue and Gray Reunion of Civil War Veterans held in Knoxville. The medal highlights both the jutting fortified wall (called a salient) at Fort Sanders and the deep trench that trapped Confederate troops attempting to scale the wall. Their heroic efforts and the brilliant strategies of Federal engineer Orlando M. Poe who reinforced and strengthened the fort, are honored in the scene depicted here.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bills, John Houston
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Garden Plan of the Pillars
Pillars, Garden Plan
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Garden Study Club of Nashville, Parthenon Press
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This drawing of the "Garden Plan of the Pillars" was created by J.E. Wood, Jr. for the History of Homes and Gardens of Tennessee. It depicts a seven section garden that is numbered according to a key provided on the drawing.

John Houston Bills, a close friend and contemporary of President James K. Polk, added a wing and a second story to this house in the small town of Bolivar, Tennessee, which is located in lower West Tennessee, surrounded by plantation lands. He also designed the home's formal garden. During the Civil War, to which he was heartily opposed, he had cordial relations with Union officers passing through and occupying the town, even as his son in law, Marshall Polk, a nephew of James K. and Sarah Childress Polk, served with Confederate forces. He built a small cottage behind The Pillars, for his daughter Evalina Bills Polk, so that she could stay close to her family while her husband was away at war.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Gardens

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Newman, Robert Loftin (1827-1912)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert E. Lee
Portrait of General Robert E. Lee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of a pair of portraits (with Stonewall Jackson) that may have been created in Clarksville, Tennessee, where Newman is known to have lived both before and after the Civil War. The other pair is in a private collection that originated in Clarksville, Tennessee.

Artist Robert Loftin Newman, a Virginian who had a studio in Clarksville, Tennessee in 1858, served in the Confederate Army. In 1864, he designed a flag for the Confederacy, which he sent to Jefferson Davis with a letter on March 12th. After the war, he returned to Tennessee and was living in Nashville by the early 1870s, where he called on other artists and prominent former Confederates to assist in his attempt to establish an Academy of Fine Arts. He spent his final years in New York City, where he had a major exhibition in 1894 at Knoedler Gallery. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Clarksville. These beautifully drawn portraits are among Newman's only known Civil War themed works.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Belmont gardens in History of Homes and Gardens of Tennessee
Gardens at Belmont Mansion, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Garden Study Club of Nashville, Parthenon Press
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This garden plan, showing curved paths surrounding statuary and fountains in a formal garden with a house and other structures surrounded by a perimeter of trees was drawn as if from above.

The formal gardens of Belmont Mansion, an Italian villa-style home, were located on a large piece of acreage on the outskirts of Nashville. The mansion's furnishings and garden would have reflected the latest taste for Adelicia Hayes Acklen was one of the wealthiest women in Nashville. She traveled to Europe after the Civil War and returned with the type of statuary and furnishings commonly associated with the "grand tour."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hunt-Phelan Garden Plan
Garden Plan, Hunt-Phelan Place, Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Garden Study Club of Nashville, Parthenon Press
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This drawing of a garden by J. Frazer Smith includes an illustration of a peacock in the left corner. The irregularly shaped ovals making up the formal garden are labeled "boxwoods" and "Cherokee roses" and a rectangular plot behind the formal garden is labeled "vegetable garden."

This drawing shows the formal garden of what is known today as the Hunt-Phelan home. A Greek-Revival Memphis mansion built in 1835, it was owned by William Hunt, whose wife inherited it from her father, during the Civil War. The gardens, reputedly designed by a French architect, were part of a master plan for the whole property that included the driveway, walking paths, ornamental shrubs, and historic trees.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elmwood Cemetery
Child's Gravestone, Elmwood Cemetery, Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An elaborate carved limestone grave marker featuring a vase of flowers inside a scalloped shell, which stands on a rock formation. Text on an unfurled ribbon below the vase reads: Ida Louisa & Mary Emily. Legible birth and death dates on left side reveal that one of

This tombstone is located in Memphis's Elmwood Cemetery. The birth and death dates legible on the left side reveal that one or the other of the two girls buried here was born September 17, 1860 and died on August 28, 1862.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entrance to Confederate Cemetery, Chattanooga, Tenn.
Confederate Cemetery Gate, Chattanooga, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This stone gate and wall have a rusticated castle-like appearance. An inscription on the cornerstone of the gateway arch reads: "Erected in 1901 by the Daughters of the Confederacy, Chapter 81, Chattanooga, Tennessee, to commemorate the valor and the heroism that our Confederate Soldiers Displayed in the battle for our beloved southland in the war from 1861-1865 in fraternal recognition of N.B. Forrest Camp, UCV."

Chattanooga's Confederate Cemetery, which holds more than 1100 Confederate burials, sits on three acres of land adjacent to the City Cemetery. Even though a 30 foot monument within Chattanooga's Confederate Cemetery was dedicated by the Ladies Memorial Society on 10 May 1877, this substantial limestone tower and arch and adjacent crenellated wall were not erected until several decades later by a local chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy ( founded 1894) and a male fraternal organization, the United Confederate Veterans (founded 1889).

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gutherz, Carl (1844-1907)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sunset after Appomattox
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A weary Robert E. Lee sits beside his horse on a fallen log, his hat on his knee, sword and scabbard touching the ground, and ungloved hand to his temple. The pink sky suggests a sunset scene.

This painting of Confederate General Robert E. Lee and his horse by Swiss-born artist Carl Gutherz portrays the Confederate general after the April 9, 1865 battle at Appomattox, the final engagement of the war in Virginia. Gutherz positions the general on a large fallen tree, a possible allusion to the fall of the Confederacy. This painting is thought to have been exhibited at the 1897 Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Since it is not in the catalog of the Fine Arts Department or the Womans' Department, it is likely to have been displayed in Confederate Memorial Hall. Art historian Stanton Thomas has suggested that this was an effort by Carl Gutherz to create a grand history painting for the Lost Cause audience, an idea possibly suggested by Gutherz's uncle-in-law John Tyler Morgan, U.S. Senator from Alabama. However, the portrait of the former Confederate commander as tired and vulnerable rather than confident and heroic may not have pleased the public for which it was intended.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lee, Robert E.; United States-- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Pictorial Works

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dickson-Williams Mansion, North Irish & West Church Streets, Greeneville, Greene, TN
Garden of Dickson-Williams Mansion. Greeneville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1958 drawing from ca. 1850 daguerreotype, photo by Ray Moody

This is a photograph of what appears to be a charcoal drawing of a substantial two-story brick house with double chimneys on the gable ends. There is a formal garden with curving paths and trees in front of the house.
Confederate officer John Hunt Morgan spent a night at the Dickson-Williams Mansion before being discovered. He was killed as he tried to escape through the vineyard.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elmwood Cemetery Landscape
Confederate Rest, Elmwood Cemetery, Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white image of a cemetery landscape with magnolia trees surrounding a raised area with a central monument, a short stack of steps, and stones laid out in a line below.

The "Confederate Rest" section of Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis was established during the Civil War. Former Confederate soldiers continued to be buried there over the decades and "Decoration Day" was celebrated by well-known figures including Jefferson Davis and Nathan Bedford Forrest in the 1870s. Today the section is surrounded by large magnolia trees.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gutherz, Carl (1844-1907)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Missing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A woodland scene with a brightly-dressed dead soldier lying in leaves on the forest floor and a bird on a branch above him.

Carl Gutherz arrived in Memphis with his family from Switzerland in 1860, when he was 16. His brother Fred joined the Confederate Army as an engineer. Too young to serve, Carl found work as a draftsman for a Memphis arms foundry and is reported to have smuggled contraband for the Confederate troops. After the war, Carl, determined to make an art career, returned to Europe. He was in Paris from 1869 to 1871, studying for a time at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts. Upon his return to the United States he became an art instructor in St. Louis, helping to establish the St. Louis School and Museum of Fine Arts. During his second tenure in Paris (1884-1896) he attended the Academie Julian. This poignant depiction of a dead soldier in the woods, who can no longer hear the song of a bird, may have been intended to reference both the American Civil War and the Franco Prussian war. The soldier's uniform bears a resemblance to those of the Zouave units, which were adapted from the French elite soldier corps by both Confederate and Union armies. According to art historian Stanton Thomas, the 154th Tennessee Volunteer Regiment in which Gutherz's brother Fred enlisted was also called the Memphis Zouaves.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Artists; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Pictorial Works

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mother and Child
Portrait of African American Woman and Boy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This formal studio portrait depicts a well-dressed young African American woman seated in a carved wood gothic chair with a boy about 8-10 years old standing to her left and resting his right arm on her shoulder. The woman is fashionably dressed in fitted gown with black ribbon tie at the collar and embroidered bolero-type jacket. The boy wears a double-breasted wood or cotton homespun suit and collarless white shirt.

This photograph, likely taken in Memphis soon after the Civil War, may depict former a formerly enslaved young woman and her young son. Both wear serious expressions, and she holds what appears to be a bible in her lap. Commissioning a formal portrait like this one represents the transition into a society free from slavery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gutherz, Frederick G.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: At Work in Camp Near Kennesaw Mountain, June 24, 1864
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing consists of a vignette of a seated man drawing next to a wagon, and two corner sections showing a tent on right and a log fortification on left. A large case on the ground bears the letters "F.G. Gutherz"

During the Civil War, Gutherz served in the First Tennessee Volunteer Regiment, C.S.A as an army engineer. He was with Confederate forces fighting Sherman in North Georgia in 1864. As indicated by the inscription across the bottom, the man at work next to the tent is probably Gutherz himself.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Catherine Hunt
Portrait of Catherine Hunt Holding Hunt Child
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This round black and white photograph depicts a young African American woman holding a white baby.

Catherine Hunt was a slave to the William Hunt Family of Memphis prior to the Civil War. This photograph shows her as a smiling young woman holding a happy white baby close to her chest and nestling his or her head with her cheek.The Hunt home was an imposing brick mansion on the outskirts of downtown Memphis. It served as temporary residence for both Confederate and Union officers during the war and is also thought to have been a Freedmen's School for several years afterwards. Perhaps Catherine had the opportunity to attend the school or even to teach there as Memphis received a large population of ex-slaves from the surrounding area during and after the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: O'Sullivan, Timothy (1840-1882)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gettysburg, Pa. Alfred R. Waud, artist of Harper's Weekly, sketching on battlefield
Waud, Alfred R. (1828-1891) sketching on battlefield at Gettysburg
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the left side of a stereograph. It shows a bearded man in dark jacket and light-colored trousers and boots. He is wearing a flat-topped hat with a wide brim, seated on a rock and balancing a sketchpad on his upraised right thigh and knee.

This photograph of British-born artist Alfred Rudolph Waud (1828-1891), a special artist for Harper's Weekly, was taken by Timothy H. O'Sullivan (1840-1882) at Gettysburg. He studied at the Government School of Design in London, then emigrated to the US in 1850. Waud executed action sketches for the New York Illustrated News in 1860 and for Harper's Weekly from 1861 to 1865, covering a great deal of action in the eastern theater as he followed the Union Army of the Potomac. Since photographic reproduction was not yet possible for newspapers, battles were often covered by such sketches, which were quickly converted into wood engravings for publication. Waud continued to produce editorial artwork for Harper's and Century Magazine in the post-war decades. The Library of Congress owns an extensive collection of Waud drawings and sketches.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Artists; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Pictorial works; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Portraits; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Battlefields
Building a Future

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wood, Thomas Waterman (1823-1903)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: His First Vote, 1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This three-quarter length image of a bearded African American man in young middle age shows him holding a folded white paper in his right hand as he moves forward. He stands next to a stone wall that has remnants of former posters or notices, the word "black" incised into the wall and visible at top is what appears to be a sign with the printed words "the polls."

After Alfred R. Waud's cover image "The First Vote" was published in Harper's Weekly in late 1867, anticipating the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment granting African American males the right to vote, other artists, like Thomas Waterman Wood, picked up the theme. Here Wood has chosen to portray a young middle aged man with hands worn by work and rumpled clothing and hat. His eyes and expression appear bright and hopeful as he approaches the poll to cast a vote for the first time in his life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--African Americans

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vizetelly, Frank (1830-1883)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cotton Burners on the Borders of SW Tennessee & Mississippi Surprised by Federal Scouts [Near Memphis, Tennessee, 1862 May-June]
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Illustrated London News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published as a wood engraving, Illustrated London News, 9 August 1862

Foreground shows uniformed men burning bales of cotton. The two-story house in middle ground has inscriptions written across the drawing. Mounted uniformed troops gallop into the scene from around the back of the house.

Frank Vizetelly was a British correspondent for the Illustrated London News. He wrote on verso of this image, "Cotton Burners on the border of SW Tennessee and Mississippi surprised by Federal Scouts." Vizetelly described the scene of southern soldiers surprised by Indiana cavalry while destroying bales of cotton as "frightened whites and negroes looked on from the house." The Confederate government had forbidden the sale of cotton to the "enemy" in 1861. In order to prevent their falling into the hands of those who could prosper from its sale, Confederate soldiers sometimes destroyed cotton stores.

oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Charles Desilver
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the state of Tennessee with insets for Knoxville and Nashville.

Tennessee, with its networks of turnpikes, railroads, and rivers afforded many opportunities for the transportation of troops and materials during the Civil War. Diarists like L. Virginia Smith French provide first-hand knowledge of troop movements.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville City and Business Directory, for 1860-1861
Map of the City of Nashville and Suburbs
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: L.P. Williams & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Street map of Nashville, including railroads and street grid of North Nashville. "Drawn and engraved especially for the Nashville City Directory."

At the beginning of the war, Nashville was a major supply center for the Confederacy with its central location and railroads. When Union forces occupied the city, many prominent residents remained in their homes, cooperating with the occupying forces, sometimes even engaging in business, in the hope that their property would be safe.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fred Gutherz and His Mother, Henrietta Luscher Gutherz
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Peplow & Balch, Star Gallery, Memphis, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of a young man standing beside seated middle aged woman. He appears to be about 18-20 years old. On the back of this card is a handwritten poem that begins: "When far in distant lands..."

This formal portrait of Fred G. Gutherz is inscribed on the back "To Dear Mother." Although he is not in uniform, this may have been taken just prior to his leaving for war. Gutherz served in the First Tennessee Volunteer Regiment, C.S.A as an army engineer. He later served with the Confederate forces fighting Sherman in North Georgia in 1864. Fred Gutherz left a number of camp drawings from his time of service. His brother, Carl, too young to serve, became well-known as an artist. He commemorated his feelings about the Civil War in artwork, most of which was created many years later.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Davis, Theodore (1840-1894)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Best Way Up Lookout in '63
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two crouching figures lead the viewer's eye into a deforested landscape with the remains of a house and chimney. The image is signed in the lower left "Theo R. Davis 1863."

This image of Lookout Mountain depicts the route of Union soldiers, who came straight up the face of the hill by the Cravens House to capture the strategic location held by the Confederates. The Cravens House is shown here as just a foundation and chimney. Historian Jim Hoobler believes that Union troops stripped off the wood siding to keep as souvenirs of their heroic victory.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Davis, Theodore (1840-1894)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Showing Western & Atlantic Depot and Crutchfield Hotel
Chattanooga in 1863 The Limestone Bridge near the W.& A. Depot
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scene depicting a city (Chattanooga) against a mountainous landscape. Two mounted soldiers and three standing figures are shown in foreground. Two long buildings, possibly both depots, are shown at left. Signed lower left :"Theo R. Davis 1863"

Theodore Davis (1840-1894) was a "Special Artist" for news magazines such as Harper's Weekly and Leslie's Illustrated Weekly, illustrating news reports from the front. He was in the Chattanooga area in 1863 and 1864. The annotations on this drawing mention a limestone bridge and the Crutchfield House, as well as the Western & Atlantic Depot. The Western & Atlantic Railroad connected Tennessee to Georgia at Chattanooga.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sketch Map of Chattanooga
Sketch Map Vicinity of Chattanooga
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of Chattanooga, Tennessee, and vicinity with locations and dates, as well as notations about troop positions and movements, of battles of Chickamauga and Lookout Mountain.

Theodore Davis (1840-1894) was a "Special Artist" for news magazines such as Harper's Weekly and Leslie's Illustrated Weekly, illustrating news reports from the front. He was in the Chattanooga area in 1863 and 1864. While he may have done this at the time of the battles, Davis also made drawings for various publications in the decades after the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New map of Kentucky and Tennessee from authentic reports of county surveyors throughout the states of Kentucky and Tennessee with a new key for measuring distances and specifying localities
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Middleton Strobridge & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color map of Kentucky and Tennessee with insets of Memphis and Louisville. The completed railroad lines running from Louisville to Nashville, Nashville to Chattanooga, and Chattanooga to Bristol are depicted on the map in blue. A decorative border with details at the four corners surrounds the map.

At the beginning of the war, East Tennessee was occupied by the Confederacy. Union sympathizers like Christopher A. Haun from Greene County Tennessee, carried out a plot to burn river and railroad bridges along the lines of the East Tennessee & Georgia and East Tennessee & Virginia railroads, shown here in blue as a continuous line, to impede the Confederate advance in November 1861.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Northern Georgia and Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: J. T. Paterson & Co., Augusta, Georgia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color topographic map showing lower central portion of East Tennessee and upper portion of Northwest Georgia with inset showing Chattanooga and vicinity. Has ornamental border with stylized floral design.

This map shows the topography of the Tennessee River valley at Chattanooga's Moccasin Bend. The battles of Chickamauga and Lookout Mountain in 1863 were fought on this rugged terrain which was the gateway for Union occupation of the Atlantic South.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Negley, Nashville, Tenn.
Postcard of Fort Negley
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Chicago: Curt Teich & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial view of a fortification with rectangular wooden stockade inside earthworks with pointed ramparts.

Fort Negley was built in 1862 by the Union Army under General John S. Negley of Pennsylvania. Many African Americans, including former slaves from Tennessee, were employed in the erection of the fort, which was sited on a prominent hilltop southwest of the city of Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sketch of Dover, Stewart Co. (Tenn.) Showing the Site of the U.S. Military Cemetery at Fort Donelson and Its Surroundings
Fort Donelson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn pictorial map depicting part of the fort itself, the Cumberland River,and the town of Dover. A red line highlights a section labeled "military cemetery." Below it the word "Freestate" is written and in parenthesis: "camp of contrabands."

This document is one of the very few to identify a location and approximate size for a "contraband camp." Such camps were often found near Union fortifications. Many African American former slaves and other persons who had escaped through enemy lines sought protection and sometimes employment as Union forces coming into the South. Since Tennessee was in the northernmost portion of the western war theater, some of the earliest contraband camps were established in or around strategic transportation corridors, such as at Dover, at Memphis, and at Grand Junction, an important railroad intersection between Memphis and Corinth, Mississippi.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Bell Brownlow
Brownlow, John Bell
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust-length photograph of man in Union officer's uniform, looking to his right.

John Bell Brownlow (1839-1922) was the son of outspoken Unionist newspaper editor William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow. He and his younger brother, James Patton Brownlow (1842-1879), both served in the Union army. Their sister, Susan, who chafed under Confederate control of Knoxville early in the war, traveled north with her father to promote the Union cause.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rev. William Blount Carter
Carter, William Blount, portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of a formally dressed man, slim, with curly dark hair, standing with his right hand resting on a leather-bound book atop a cloth-draped table.

The Reverend William Blount Carter, a Presbyterian minister from a prominent East Tennessee family of Unionists, was a graduate of Princeton University. His brother, Samuel P. Carter, a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy, was commander of U.S. forces in southeastern Kentucky early in the war, and his brother James was in command of the 2nd Tennessee Volunteer Infantry. Reverend Carter is widely thought to have played a role in encouraging the bridge burnings by Union supporters in upper East Tennessee in November 1861.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Parson W.G. Brownlow, The Union Patriot of Tennessee
Brownlow, William Gannaway
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: New York Illustrated News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust-length black and white image of a middle-aged man in formal dress on the front page of the New York Illustrated News. Caption beneath image reads: "Parson W.G. Brownlow, the Union Patriot of Tennessee."

William Gannaway Brownlow (1805-1877), who was known as "Parson Brownlow" because he had been a circuit-riding minister, was an outspoken newspaper editor in Knoxville, Tennessee at the outset of the Civil War. During Confederate occupation of the city, Brownlow went north on a lecture tour, accompanied by his daughter, Susan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. John Guards Flag
Flag of the St. John Guards, Woodbury, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This long horizontal banner has two wide red stripes top and bottom, a white stripe with the letters "St. John Guards" in the middle, and a blue square at upper left with eight white stars.

The flag was made by Miss Anne E. Coleman, Miss Paralee Wood, Miss Helen Wood, Mrs. Fatima Sewell St. John, Mrs. St. John, Mrs. John Abraham Wood, Mrs. Fannie St. John, Miss Jennie St. John, whose names appear on the white stars. It was raised at Woodbury (Tenn.) for a Confederate unit apparently led by a member of the St. John family. The flag was captured at Fort Donelson by the Federal Army. It was later returned to Woodbury.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Orth, John G.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Fort Sanders, Knoxville, Tennessee, showing the Confederate assault of Nov. 29, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This hand-drawn map shows the plan of Fort Sanders from an aerial perspective. It is labeled with directional information, shows railroad tracks, and has symbols that appear to represent cannons drawn in red ink. Written on verso in lead pencil: Drawn by John G. Orth (Arcadia, Ohio). Went with Army 8/22/1862 for 3 yrs. Mustered out with Company 6/24/1865.

Fort Sanders, which sat atop a fortified hill just north of the Kingston Pike in Knoxville, Tennessee, was built by U.S. Army troops under the direction of West Point-trained engineer Orlando M. Poe. Originally named Fort Loudon, Poe suggested changing the name to honor his friend Brigadier General William Sanders who was killed Nov. 19, 1863, ten days before Confederate soldiers were soundly defeated trying to regain control of Knoxville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Full-length portrait of Buell in uniform.
Gen Don Carlos Buell was commander of the federal troops who entered and took Nashville on February 25, 1862, after the Confederate surrender at Fort Donelson left the upriver city vulnerable.

Camp of Tennessee Colored Battery, Johnsonville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This black and white photograph shows men in rain gear working with heavy cannons in muddy landscape near railroad tracks beside a large river.

Johnsonville, on the Tennessee River, was an important strategic point for the Union army. Union troops, including members of the United States Colored Troops, completed the railroad from Nashville to the Tennessee River after Middle and West Tennessee were occupied.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Knaffl & Bro
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of Fort Saunders [sic]
Souvenir Card, Knoxville, 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: S.B. Newman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Card printed with text in blue ink on gray paper. Card image is a photograph of a painting that is referred to in text on verso as: "painting 8 x 20 feet, on view at 242 Gay Street" and inscribed "Photo by Knaffl & Bro From Painting" in lower right corner.

This souvenir card was apparently created for a reunion of the Battle of Fort Sanders (name is mis-spelled Saunders) in Knoxville on 7, 8, & 9 October 1890. It features a photograph, signed by local photographers Knaffl & Bro., of a panoramic painting (perhaps by Lloyd Branson). Branson is known to have painted at least one painting showing the battle, which is shown here as if seen from a Confederate fortification on the opposite side of the river.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gumpert, G.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Our Country's Flag
Beneath the stars and stripes there stand our sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: G. Andre & Company, Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An illustration of a young man in uniform holding a flag on a staff in front of a line of white tents. Printed below the image are the words "Song Composed & Dedicated to His Excellency Abraham Lincoln, President of the United States, by G. Gumpert."

This colorful sheet music cover was published during the first year of the Civil War. Popular music, often played in civic settings, served to build morale as the country mustered for war. It is interesting to note that this song includes lyrics in German, reminding us that many young immigrants and first generation Americans either enlisted or were drafted into the armies on both sides. The young Union soldier holding the flag wears a uniform consisting of a blouse shirt and pants (no jacket) and neither he nor the camp behind him show any signs of the war weariness that set in once the early battles of the Civil War revealed the Confederate army to be a much more serious fighting force than the U.S. Army had anticipated.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cyclorama of the Battle of Gettysburg
Battle of Gettysburg Cyclorama
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Close-up black and white photograph showing the Cyclorama of the Battle of Gettysburg at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Shows the front entrance of the building, which was a circular structure.

Inside the circular walls of the Cyclorama was a painting that depicted the charge of Gen. Pickett's Division at the stone wall on the 3rd day of the Battle of Gettysburg. This work is said to have required 16 months of labor by 13 artists. Seven tons of paint were used. The exhibit was popular with Union and Confederate veterans alike and contained many relics from the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Drawing of Dickson-Williams House
Dickson-Williams Mansion, Greeneville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white outline sketch of the Dickson-Williams house and gardens, including vineyard.

Benson Lossing (1813-1891), a journalist and illustrator in New York City, published a narrative sketchbook on the American Revolution in 1853. He attempted a similar project after the Civil War, creating ink drawings to turn into wood engravings for publication. The Tennessee State Museum owns a small collection of drawings he made in Tennessee, including this image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Morris Gallery of the Cumberland, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Morse's Gallery of the Cumberland, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Portrait of boy soldier]
Boy soldier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of a boy who appears to be 8-10 years old, with arms crossed, wearing a loose uniform, boots, a hat with a tilted brim and badge, and a holster with sidearm.

This image is part of a Civil War glass negative collection at the Library of Congress. A number of cartes-de-visite from Morse's Gallery of the Cumberland, a photographic studio in Nashville, have been recorded. Many depict soldiers. The fact that they are both Union and Confederate suggest that the studio continued to operate during the war, even as Nashville changed hands. Even though enlistment age for Union soldiers was eighteen, some younger boys were admitted with parental consent, while others managed to enter the armed forces surreptitiously.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Child soldiers

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Confederate Currency with Lucy Pickens Image
Dollar bill, Confederate, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Confederate States of America, Richmond, Virginia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Confederate States of America, one dollar bill issued at Richmond on June 2, 1862. Sailing ship at center. Oval vignette with engraving of young dark haired woman in lower right corner.

Lucy Pettway Holcombe Pickens (1832-1899), of LaGrange, Tennessee, was married to South Carolina governor Francis Wilkinson Pickens, a former ambassador to Russia, when the Civil War began. The beautiful young First Lady of South Carolina is said to have sold jewelry given to her in Russia to support the Confederacy. Her image was used on dollar bills issued in 1862 and 1863, and on a one hundred dollar issued in 1864.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Richardson and Cox, engravers
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hanging of Fry and Hensie near the Railroad, by Colonel Leadbetter
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William G. Brownlow, Sketches of the Rise, Progress, and Decline of Secession; with a Narrative of Personal Adventures Among the Rebels (Philadelphia: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., 1862), p. 311

Two men clad in shirts and trousers hang by ropes from tree branches. They are taunted by a man with a cane standing on a train platform next to a rail car while people watch from the platform and peer out of the rail car windows.

Henry Fry and Jacob M. Hensie (Hinshaw) were among a group of five Union loyalists in East Tennessee who attempted to disrupt Confederate troop movements by destroying bridges along the East Tennessee & Virginia and East Tennessee & Georgia railroad lines on the night of November 8-9, 1861. The "bridge burners," who believed they had the support of the Lincoln administration and that the United States Army was about to sweep into in East Tennessee and liberate it from Confederate authorities, were executed for their actions. Master potter Christopher A. Haun, who was also among their number, was hanged in Knoxville on 10 December 1861.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: nited States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Destruction and Pillage--Union
Walking a Fine Line
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Richardson and Cox, engravers
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Execution of Jacob Harmon and his son Henry
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image depicts a man and a youth standing on a wooden platform as nooses are placed around their necks by two other men while a uniformed soldier stands alongside with sword raised in the air. In the foreground are several uniformed soldiers next to a wagon. There are several agitated bystanders, a man on horseback, and a Confederate flag in the right section of the image.

Jacob Harmon and his son Henry belonged to a group of Union loyalists who destroyed the Lick Creek Bridge on the East Tennessee & Virginia Railroad on the night of November 8-9, 1861. One of their number, Christopher Haun, a master potter, was hanged by Confederate officials in Knoxville on 10 December 1861. These men, along with Henry Fry and Jacob Hensie or Hinshaw, were among the five executed for their actions disrupting the movement of Confederate troops and supplies into upper East Tennessee. This image appeared on page 319 of William G. Brownlow's Sketches of the Rise, Progress, and Decline of Secession; with a Narrative of Personal Adventures Among the Rebels (Philadelphia: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., 1862)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: nited States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Destruction and Pillage--Union
Walking a Fine Line

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wood, Thomas Waterman (1823-1903)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Contraband, the Recruit, and the Veteran
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Harper's Weekly
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The paintings depicted in these engravings were painted in 1866. The caption indicates that they were photographed for the magazine by "Rockwood." (?).
Based on the titles, these three images of an African American man portray him as a contraband in ragged clothes, as a recruit with a new uniform and gun over his shoulder, and as a wounded veteran.

This page from Harper's Weekly May 4, 1867, describes three paintings that Wood had on display at the National Academy of Design in New York. According to the text, they were "made from studies in Tennessee during the late war." Wood was elected an Associate of the National Academy of Design, perhaps on the basis of these works, and moved to New York. He became a full member of the Academy in 1871. In later years he served as President of the National Academy as well as the American Watercolor Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Branson, Lloyd (1853-1925)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bethel Cemetery Monument
Confederate Monument, Knoxville, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image shows an obelisk of rusticated blocks topped by a figure of a soldier.

Artist Lloyd Branson, one of the most respected painters of 19th century Knoxville, was commissioned by the Ladies Memorial Association to design this monument. The monument was carved by a former Union soldier. Many Confederate cemeteries and monuments were funded and cared for by women's organizations since federal funds could only be used for national cemeteries.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Simplot, Alexander (1837-1914)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Capture of Fort Henry, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Harper's Weekly
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bottom half of image shows the naval battle at Fort Henry and above is a roundel with an image of the fort's plan. On left is an illustration of the "secession ordnance stores" and on the right, a corner of the fortification with a cannon.

Alexander Simplot, 1837-1914, was a "special artist" who traveled with Union forces from 1861-1863. He drew and painted several images of naval battles, including one at Memphis in June of 1862, which was also published in Harper's Weekly.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schrader, Theodore
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville and the camp of the Sixteenth Regiment of Ills. Vols. Inft. At Edgefield, Tennessee, circa 1863-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A pictorial representation in lithographic form of Nashville during the Civil War, with the camp of the Illinois 16th Volunteer Regiment at Edgefield in the foreground. The Cumberland River is seen in the background with gunboats and riverboats depicted. The state capitol building can be seen in the background overlooking the city of Nashville. Structures featured within the camp are the guard house, the headquarters, the hospital, the sutler, and the housing for the band.

Most of the lithograph depicts camp activities as might be seen during the Civil War. The lithograph was created by Theodore Schrader of St. Louis, Missouri. The 16th Regiment Illinois Infantry was organized at Quincy, Illinois, and mustered in May 24, 1861. They marched from Tuscumbia, Alabama to Nashville from August 25 through September 15, 1862. They saw action at Columbia on September 10, 1862. They participated in the Siege of Nashville from September 15 through November 6 of 1862.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States. Army. Illinois Infantry Regiment, 16th

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Boucher, Jack
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Immanuel Episcopal Church, LaGrange, Interior View of Church, Looking North Towards the Main Entrance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS)
Brick structure with Gothic pointed windows and Greek revival details.

This Protestant Episcopal Church was one of the first established in rural West Tennessee. It was built by slaves of Mrs. Mary Hayes Gloster, a widow from Warrington, N.C. Traditional lore states that the pews of this church were used to make coffins for Union officers. This area of West Tennessee, which was near the rail lines at Grand Junction, was occupied by Union troops early in the war. In fact, General Grant ordered the establishment of one of the first contraband camps in Tennessee at Grand Junction.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Homer, Winslow (1836-1910)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Seventy-Ninth Regiment (Highlanders) New York State Militia
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Harper's Weekly
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 79th New York Highlanders was originally formed as part of the New York State militia. They fought in the defense of Knoxville at Campbell's Station and Fort Sanders in November 1863. A monument erected in honor of the 79th NY Highlanders still stands at 16th and Clinch in the Fort Sanders neighborhood of Knoxville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Linn, R(oyan). M. (d. 1872)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Children at Lookout Mountain]
Children at Gallery Point Lookout
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph shows five children: four white boys varying in age from about 5 to 12 years old, and one African American boy, probably age 10 to 12, seated on a rock formation high above a wooded landscape.

This group of children are posed upon the "Gallery Point" lookout near the studio of Charles and Royan Linn, Chattanooga photographers whose Civil War and post-Civil War tourist portraits often depicted their subjects next to dramatic vistas of Lookout Mountain and the Tennessee river valley below.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew Johnson to Abraham Lincoln and Edwin M. Stanton, Tuesday, September 06, 1864 (Telegram reporting death of John Hunt Morgan)
Morgan, John Hunt, death of
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This telegram was sent by Andrew Johnson, Military Governor of Tennessee, to President Abraham Lincoln and Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton, to report the death of Confederate General John Hunt Morgan at Greeneville, Tennessee on 4 September 1864.

General John Hunt Morgan was surprised by federal troops under the command of General Alvin Gillem in an early morning raid on the Dickson-Williams mansion in Greeneville, Tennessee. He was shot by a Union soldier after being cornered in a vineyard at the edge of the home's formal gardens. The news of the death of Morgan, who had inspired many loyal followers with raids on Union troops in Tennessee and Kentucky, was important enough to merit sending by telegraph--the fastest means of communication during the Civil War.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Johnson, Andrew, -- 1808-1875 -- Correspondence; Morgan, John Hunt; United States--History--Civil War--1861-1865

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wyon, Leonard C(harles), (1826-1891)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Prize Medal for Cotton from the Crystal Palace Exhibition, London, (awarded to Dr. Samuel Bond), 1851
Medal for Cotton, Great Exhibition of the Industry of All Nations, London, 1851
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the reverse side of the medal. It shows what appears to be a toga-clad Roman emperor placing a wreath on the head of a kneeling young woman, while four other women (perhaps representing virtues) stand behind her. The inscription: DISSOCIATA LOCIS CONCORDI PACE LIGAVIT appears around the top edge of the medal. Type along the bottom edge includes the name of the artist who designed the medal: Leonard C. Wyon. The name S.Bond is engraved on the edge of the medal.

This medal was awarded to Dr. Samuel Bond, a Memphis cotton producer, who, along with nine other Americans, including fellow Memphian John Pope, won prize medals in the category of "Vegetable and Animal Substances Chiefly Used in Manufactures" at the 1851 world's industrial fair held at the Crystal Palace in London. A commentary in the official catalogue of the exposition noted that all of the cotton on display came from countries other than Great Britain, and that the English writer hoped that soon "encouragement given to the growth of cotton in our Indian and colonial possessions shall enable us to dispense with the slave-grown cotton of America." Reference: The Illustrated Exhibitor, A Tribute to the World's Industrial Jubilee (London: John Cassell, 1851), p. 485.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: cotton; slavery

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Patton Brownlow
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James Patton Brownlow (1842-1879) was the son of outspoken Unionist newspaper editor William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow. He and his older brother John Bell Brownlow (1839-1922) both served in the Union army. James was acclaimed a leader and by the end of the war, he had attained the rank of brigadier general. Their sister, Susan, who chafed under Confederate control of Knoxville early in the war, traveled North with her father to promote the Union cause.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Poe, Orlando Metcalfe (1832-1895)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: East Tennessee North of Loudon
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This black and white topographic map of upper East Tennessee appears to have been folded or bound into a book or booklet. The text under the map reads: "prepared under the direction of Capt. O.M. Poe, Corps of Engineers & Chief Mil Div of the Mississippi, from data furnished by Capt. O.M. Poe and Professor J.M. Safford." The map bears the signature of W.L.B. Jenney, Capt. U.S.A.

This map, which shows railroad lines, ferries, roads, and bridges in the upper East Tennessee corridor, appears to have been based upon Tennessee State Geologist James M. Safford's 1855 map of the state, which would have been the most detailed topographic map available at the time. Even though several of Tennessee's railroad lines had been completed prior to 1855, Safford did not show them on his map. When issued, this map might even have been considered confidential, for this information would have been critical to the movement of troops and war supplies for both sides.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Transportation; Maps
Visualizing the War
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University;

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Brady National Photographic Art Gallery (Washington, D.C.), photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Brig. Gen. Orlando M. Poe, officer of the Federal Army
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This portrait made in the Washington studio of Mathew Brady (1823-1896) by an unknown photographer captures a seated young man facing to his right. He has a mustache and goatee and wears a federal uniform with the one-star insignia of a Brigadier General.

An 1856 graduate of West Point, Orlando Metcalfe Poe served as Chief Engineer of the Army of the Ohio and was responsible for the defenses of Knoxville in November 1863. Soon thereafter, General William T. Sherman made him Chief Engineer of the Military Division of the Mississippi. Sherman relied upon Poe's valuable services for his Atlanta Campaign, the "March to the Sea," and the Carolinas Campaign. Poe was breveted Brigadier General, United States Army, at the war's end.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Poe, Orlando M. (1832-1895)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Prize Medal for Cotton from the Crystal Palace Exhibition, London, (awarded to Dr. Samuel Bond), 1851
Front view of Medal for Cotton, Great Exhibition of the Industry of All Nations, London, 1851
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This round bronze medal features a double portrait of Queen Victoria and Price Albert shown in profile. Stamped letters around the edge of the medal include the year in Roman numerals (MDCCCLI) at bottom center and "Royal Mint" to the immediate right. The name S. Bond is engraved on the edge.

This medal was awarded to Dr. Samuel Bond, a Memphis cotton producer, who, along with nine other Americans, including fellow Memphian John Pope, won prize medals in the category of "Vegetable and Animal Substances Chiefly Used in Manufactures" at the 1851 world's industrial fair held at the Crystal Palace in London. A commentary in the official catalogue of the exposition noted that all of the cotton on display came from countries other than Great Britain, and that the English writer hoped that soon "encouragement given to the growth of cotton in our Indian and colonial possessions shall enable us to dispense with the slave-grown cotton of America." Reference: The Illustrated Exhibitor, A Tribute to the World's Industrial Jubilee (London: John Cassell, 1851), p. 485.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [G.P.A. Healy, half-length portrait, facing front]
Portrait of George Peter Alexander Healy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oval portrait photograph of a dark-haired man with mustache and tiny goatee dressed in formal clothing.

George Peter Alexander Healy (1813-1894) may have been the best-known portraitist of his era when he painted portraits of President James K. Polk and Sarah Childress Polk at the White House, circa 1845. He was a favorite of Louis-Philippe of France, for whom he had traveled to Tennessee to paint a portrait of former president Andrew Jackson in 1845, which proved to be the last year of his life.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George [attributed]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Sanders, Knoxville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This black and white image depicts a tree-stump studded landscape with trench and ramped earth fortification. A section of wooden railing is visible atop the earth mound at right.

The landscape in the foreground is now thought by scholars to show a portion of Fort Sanders. It was long thought to have been taken by photographer Sam A. Cooley, of Fort McAllister, South Carolina (near Savannah, GA) because the negative was found in a sleeve labeled Fort McAllister. However, since Cooley is not recorded as having been in Tennessee, the photograph has been attributed to George Barnard, who, as chief photographer for the U.S. Army's topographical engineers, was headquartered in Tennessee in 1863 and 186.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maj. Nathaniel F. Cheairs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Full-length formal studio portrait photograph of a slender middle-aged, bearded man standing at attention in formal uniform with a belted sash and a dark-brimmed hat bearing insignia.

Major Nathaniel Francis Cheairs (1818-1914), married Spring Hill, Tennessee, neighbor Susan Peters McKissack in 1841. They lived at Rippa Villa, a brick home built from local McKissack bricks. According to the records of Maury County's Rose Hill Cemetery, Cheairs enlisted with the Third Tennessee Infantry and served as a field officer with the Bigby Grays. He survived the war and returned to run his large plantation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Roane Iron Company's Amended Addition to the City of Chattanooga, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Plat map filed on October 19, 1886, with officials of the City of Chattanooga, Hamilton County, Tennessee, showing administrative and housing buildings, as well as the company railroad line.

Former Union general John T. Wilder, whose Chattanooga residence, along with that of prominent iron man H.S. Chamberlain, is shown on this map, was one of the founders of the Roane Iron Company. He also oversaw the company's expansion into Chattanooga where it added to the city's growing prosperity.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barnard, George N. (1819-1902)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View from an elevation in front of the Capitol, Nashville, Tenn., looking west over the battle field on the first day of the fight, Dec. 15th, 1864
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: E.T. Anthony & Company, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This stereographic image shows a hillside view of large houses and smaller outbuildings stretching out towards a misty horizon. The standing water, dead-looking vegetation, and leafless trees suggest that the time of year is late fall or early winter.

Barnard was a photographer in the Topographical Branch of the Department of Engineers, Army of the Cumberland, United States Army with offices based at 89 Church Street in Nashville beginning in December 1863. He is known to have photographed federal installations, transportation networks, and battlefields in Tennessee in 1863 and 1864.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Thrilling Scene in East Tennessee: Colonel Fry and the Union Men Swearing by the Flag
East Tennessee Bridge Burners
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Harper's Weekly
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of Harper's Weekly Saturday 29 March 1862
Black and white image of men standing inside a timber frame building lit by a candle on a flag-draped table draped. The men have their hands raised in the air.

This scene was intended to represent Henry Fry and some of the other loyalists in upper East Tennessee who had attempted to burn bridges in order to disrupt Confederate movements in their area. After the November 8, 1861 burning of a bridge on the outskirts of Greeneville, five men, including Fry, were hanged for their participation. Among the group were both Fry and master potter Christopher A. Haun.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Buttre, J(ohn) C(hester), 1821-1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Pope
Portrait of Colonel John Pope
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: London: Sampson, Low, Son & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This portrait engraving accompanied a profile in: John Livingston, Portraits of Eminent Americans Now Living: With biographical and historical memoirs of their lives and actions , II. The page also includes a facsimile signature.

Colonel John Pope (1794-1865), a prominent Memphis Cotton grower, received a medal for his cotton in 1851 at London's Great Exhibition of the Industry of All Nations, now known as the "Crystal Palace" exposition. He had studied law at Yale University and served in the Alabama state legislature before settling in Tennessee. Pope, who was one of the founders of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad at Bolivar, Tennessee, in 1834, developed some 900 acres of southwestern Tennessee land in the vicinity of Memphis. An innovator and pioneer in the science of farming, he is credited with helping develop short staple cotton as a commodity.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Taking Care of Business
